I am convinced that a circular economy needs to be a fundamental element of European and national industrial policies, while national plans for member states' recovery and resilience must be based precisely on growth that is smart, sustainable and inclusive.

name: Ciarán Cuffe
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, there’s only one planet Earth and that’s why we’re here today to make laws that help the planet heal. It won’t be easy.  It’s 50 years since the singer, Marvin Gaye, asked ‘Where did all the blue skies go?’ and the question is more relevant today. We need a new relationship with our Earth and we must all play our part in realising the circular economy. On the Transport and Tourism Committee, we know the days of the internal combustion engine are numbered. We need to go electric, but a million electric cars won’t save the planet. We need to slow down, hear the birdsong and smell the flowers. We need to walk and cycle more and invest in public transport: modern trams and buses, shared and active mobility. The Ecodesign Directive must help us to achieve this.  As aviation picks up again, let’s have fairer fares that encourage rail travel. Where we need to do this is in this European Year of Rail. We also need to adopt Europe’s eco label and eco-management and audit scheme to tackle waste. The planet deserves this.

name: Claude Gruffat
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, rethinking economic circularity is not just questioning our relationship to material accumulation. It is also, and above all, radically changing the way we consume and draw endless natural resources. This is why, in addition to the industrial approach, it is essential to raise awareness in the agricultural and food sector about this problem, with the aim of minimizing its debt to nature. In this action plan for the circular economy, the Commission opens welcome doors to alternatives to a productive agricultural model that is still dominant, too resource-intensive, unsealed for the climate and destructive of jobs. Better control of inputs, reduction of dependence on plant proteins, relocation of production, recovery of waste, fight against food waste, more transparent consumer information, especially through labelling, are all tools that will help to bring agriculture finally into the era of the circular economy.

name: Arba Kokalari
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr If Europe is to meet its climate objectives, we must move away from the drudgery society and move to a circular economy in which resources are used more efficiently. The circular economy is already in full swing, in Sweden and Europe. There are innovative entrepreneurs who change their business models and drive development forward with smart solutions. It is about recycling and reuse in new ways.  Here, politics must make it much easier so that this transition gets under way as soon as possible, not put a spanner in the works. Unfortunately, however, the Greens and the Left are constantly putting forward proposals in the name of the climate that make it difficult for companies to change, without any climate benefit. In Sweden, plastic bag tax is being presented and soon a clothing tax is being presented. The European Parliament wants advertising bans and forces all companies to store spare parts of products that no one knows if they will even be used. At the same time, it stands in the way of nuclear power, new technologies such as carbon capture and easier trade in sustainable services. So much hate sensieus that we stand and import electricity from coal power in Poland. The government's new clothing tax must be stopped by the European Commission. That's why I've reported this clothing tax, and I hope you can stop it. The climate cannot afford political greenwashing from the left, but the climate needs a circular economy that makes it easier to change.

name: Simona Bonafè
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, reuse, recycling, regeneration, repair and re-use are the actions that best explain the new Circular Economy Action Plan. Actions that become even more central in this historic period, where we are facing an unprecedented health pandemic, which confronts us with the need to get our economies back on their feet, starting with the European Union's commitment to becoming a net-zero-emission continent by 2050 at the latest.  Today we consume two and a half times the resources that our planet is able to regenerate in a year. We will not be able to achieve the goal of climate neutrality without a profound transformation of our development model from a linear design, production and consumption system to a fully circular one that respects the limits of our planet. That is why it is important for the European Commission to update its circular economy action plan, defining measures and actions to be implemented over the next five years. In the last action plan, we focused on the end of life of products, setting ambitious targets for recycling and reducing landfilling, objectives on which the Commission will have to monitor their implementation in the Member States.  The aim for the future must now be to influence the first level of the waste hierarchy: prevention. The new legislation on sustainable products should be a key measure to extend sustainability measures to product design as well, and will have to take into account the requirements of durability, repairability and minimum content of recycled material in products. But we also need specific rules for the sectors with the greatest potential in terms of circularity. I am thinking in particular of textiles, construction, ICT and batteries. We have an opportunity today, with Next Generation EU, to transform the principles of the Green Deal circular economy into concrete investments and at the same time support a lasting and solid economic recovery because it is environmentally and socially sustainable.

name: Martin Hojsík
text: for the Renew group. – Mr President, in Slovakia we say that fire is a good servant, but a bad gentleman. And so it is now with plastics. Without plastic, we can no longer slowly imagine our lives. This microphone is also wrapped in plastic. They're everywhere, we've infested nature and ourselves. Weekly it's like we're eating a credit card. Plastics have become a bad gentleman. The problem is not just plastic waste. We still put toxic chemicals in plastics that harm our health. We produce more and more of them, and we produce them from fossil fuels, oil and gas. This exacerbates the climate crisis instead of helping to solve it. That is why we need not only action plans, but I call on the Commission to come up with concrete bills that will ensure that we use less plastic, actually recycle them, are made of renewable materials and free of toxic substances. Or to put it another way, we will switch to a circular economy, because otherwise plastics will not serve us, but we will use plastics.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Madam President, by definition, the respect we owe to nature, the very one that secures our living space, requires us not to waste anything of what it gives us. The new action plan for the circular economy fits well into this approach. As such, it would go in the right direction if it is recognized with certain caveats that 50% of greenhouse gas emissions and 90% of biodiversity loss are the result of the extraction and transformation of the planet's resources. This particularly important issue, however, has a twofold aspect. The first, perfectly acceptable, envisages recycling almost infinitely our mineral resources and especially energy, our plant resources feeding and regulating CO2, and even our animal resources, with respect due to animals. It is an immediate winning step, if we all participate in the reversal of the attitude of 50 years of blind and unbridled consumption. In the medium term, it is a great opportunity to reorient and re-establish our industries as a model to create more local sectors and many jobs. But there is a more worrying phase, that of the already restrictive Green Deal and the Paris Agreements, which are driven by militant environmentalism. Climate change is clearly being exploited by the proponents of global energy power. The European Union enacts its standards, risking depriving states of industrial autonomy - as yesterday, the Chinese, of their low-cost industrial power, imposed a low-cost market in Europe.  Because a recycled product costs less in both production and sales, consumers are persuaded to wages that are always as low and precarious as they keep purchasing power. This is a real danger. It is a large part of our future that is being played out on this issue, which we will vote on while denouncing the potential excesses.

name: Margrete Auken
text: verts/ALE Group. Madam President! First of all, thank you to Huitema and the other rapporteurs for a really strong report. In particular, there is an important focus on binding reduction targets. Europe's overspending is rampant. We use resources as if we had almost three planets. We must therefore reduce our consumption by two thirds! It is also important for the report to stress that the circular economy must be non-toxic and sustainable. If the circles are filled with poison, or if the consumption is too large for the planet to keep up, then it won't work.  In January, the European Environment Agency concluded in a report that increased efficiency and new technologies are not enough to make our economy sustainable. The Environment Agency also demonstrates that it is hardly possible to achieve sustainable growth, as we usually call it. In other words, we must be free from dependence on infinite economic growth and find an economy in which we can achieve well-being with prosperity and solidarity within what the earth can cope with. We need to get this difficult debate going on. We cannot simply ignore the fact that the Environment Agency's words that the biodiversity, climate and pollution crises are closely linked to economic growth. At the same time, however, we must avoid being caught up in unemployment and other misery. Society must not go to slumber. What we now need are analyses, models and concrete examples of how people and societies can thrive in a truly circular economy where the boundaries of nature are respected.

name: Pietro Fiocchi
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Sinkevičius, thank you for being here. The package is very good and full of very useful recommendations and very good concepts. Some scientists and engineers that I contacted personally in the verification of what was said ironized about the name, that is circular economy, when in fact they say it is a helical economy, starting from the fact that some materials, such as aluminum, lead, copper and steel, can be recycled endlessly, but others, such as paper and plastic, no, so sooner or later they end up either in landfills or in incinerators. However, apart from this anecdote, these are two issues that I see: one is the fact that the 2018 waste package was almost ignored by some European Member States and only partially adopted by others. So how do we achieve the 2018 targets if we raise them even higher now? Then we don't have a real system of system measurement. So how do we set ourselves new targets for 2030 if we don't know where we are now?  Having said that, I fully support commissioner Sinkevičius' work. Keep it up!

name: Mick Wallace
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Madam President, first of all well done to the rapporteur, Jan, for all his good work on this report. It’s good that the report calls on the Commission to propose targets to significantly reduced the EU’s material and consumption footprints by 2030 and bring them within planetary boundaries by 2050. Emphasising an absolute reduction in resource use is really positive. There are positive statements on textiles and fast fashion, on the right to repair, on the need for legislative measures to halve food waste by 2030, and legislative measures to tackle planned obsolescence. However, both the Commission’s plan and the report still fixate on GDP growth and consumer empowerment. GDP growth is dependent on perpetual endless resource extraction. Under capitalism, progress is defined as an increase in the total quantity of commodities that we produce and consume each year. The aim of economies should be to satisfy the basic needs and well—being of all people within planetary boundaries, regardless if the economy grows or not. Jason Hickel’s new book Less is More should be taught throughout classrooms right across Europe.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. The main means of combating climate change is the transition to an environmentally conscious and sustainable economy. This, in turn, will not be feasible if we focus only on renewing energy production. It is therefore of the utmost importance to support the circular economy, since we can only meet the emissions targets if we start this model at EU level and operate it at industrial level. What is certain is that the transition to a circular economy will create new economic and employment opportunities and bring significant environmental and social benefits through more efficient use of resources. From the member state and EU regulatory side, it is therefore particularly important to implement the Circular Economic Action Plan. I believe that even greater efforts will be needed to implement waste legislation. It is positive news that, despite the epidemic, industrial operators, such as in my country, Hungary, are already working on innovative solutions to reduce emissions.  At the individual level, adequate education and strengthening conscious customer behaviour would be very important. I call on the Committee to speed up its work already under way in these policy areas so that Member States can start the transition to a circular economy as soon as possible.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his The circular economy is essential if we in europe are to meet our ambitions in terms of the green deal, but also our goal of becoming climate neutral by 2050. If we are to make the transition to a more sustainable society, we need to shift the whole chain, from production and consumption to waste.  If everyone were to consume the way we do in Europe, we would need three globes. While people hunger, starve in parts of the world, we consume 90 million tonnes of food waste every year, and much disappears even before it is on the plate. We know that we have microplastics that go out into our oceans and poison our ecosystems, and we know that climate emissions are far more than the Paris Agreement allows. Europe must embark on a development in which we decouple our economic growth from the use of resources. We need to close the cycle. We need to get smarter in our entire use of resources.  This is also good for the jobs. This could generate 700 000 new jobs in the circular economy by 2030, and we must invest in this. That is why we welcome the Action Plan from the Commission as very good. However, we want to further flesh out some objectives. I would also like to thank Mrs Bonafè, who has done an excellent job.

name: Claudia Gamon (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Circular Economy Action Plan starts precisely where great things can be done. 45% of total CO2 emissions can somehow be attributed to the production of materials and their recovery. That number now sounds threatening. However, this also means that we are talking here about a key issue on climate protection. Making packaging recyclable and reducing plastic alone is not yet a circular economy. We need a holistic approach that starts with the design of the products, because it determines 80% of the environmental impact of products. This is also the lever for the prosperity of the future. Let us make Europe the centre of sustainable product innovation, making the workbench of the whole world reusable and recyclable for anything that should last a long time! Thank you to the rapporteur, Jan Huitema, for the great work. We are now waiting for the Commission to start with concrete and effective measures.

name: Sara Matthieu (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, you have probably already noticed it in your own household: the average life span of our dishwashers is getting shorter and shorter. You're probably also somewhere to gather a smartphone that just isn't broken. Usually the device is designed so that you can't repair it yourself. That costs us money, causes inconvenience, waste, is also not economically smart. I therefore support 100% the right to repair as a solution to the throwaway economy in this new action plan.  We are also in favour of extending the law on ecodesign to circular economy. Today it focuses only on energy, but that is how we achieve half of our European energy saving target. That's huge. Imagine how many materials, how much less we would all have if that law were extended.  In short, better products that last longer and cost less for people and the planet. That is what this plan is aiming for, and I fully support it.

name: Πέτρος Κόκκαλης (The Left).
text: Madam President, rapporteur, Mr Huitema, congratulations on the report on the circular economy. It is a very important step towards sustainability, an important objective for the completion of the green agreement. We must abandon our model of predatory and wasteful linear model of detachment, consumption and disposal of vital resources. We all know that the land is not inexhaustible but is a set of finite resources, which requires their rational, sustainable and fair exploitation. We are in complete agreement with the design of products that are durable, repairable and upgradeable, with recycling being the last option only for those products that cannot be recovered in any other way. I come from a country where waste management is problematic. The circular economy is a structural reform so that countries like Greece can invest in the future and use the Recovery and Resilience Fund to protect public health.

name: Agnès Evren (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the transition to the circular economy is potentially between 1.2 and 3 million new jobs created by 2030! Chemistry industries, SMEs specializing in recycling or maintenance, the list of players involved is very long.  For the circular economy to work, it requires a market. This market is for recycled raw materials. More concretely, it is to allow a manufacturer of plastic bottles to use recycled plastic rather than plastic directly from oil. The reality is that there is not enough demand currently on the market for secondary raw materials produced from waste. So it's up to us to develop that by stimulating that demand, which can be done in two ways.  First, by introducing mandatory recycled content into certain products. This will automatically create an increase in demand and therefore opportunities for recycled raw materials. Second, by directing consumer choices through clear and explicit labels on the design and recyclability of what they buy. In this way, they will change the market. However, the market economy can be a great opportunity for a successful ecological transition.

name: Delara Burkhardt (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In Germany alone, 500 million garments are being disposed of to make way for the next collection. Garments that were manufactured at enormous expense. And why? Because our economy follows a simple principle: take – manufacture – use and throw away. A nice principle, assuming that resources are infinitely available. If everyone were to do this the way we do in Europe, the resources available every year would have been used up by mid-May. This principle therefore belongs in the ton. In a circular economy, we develop products in such a way that waste and pollution do not arise in the first place. Products must be usable for longer and return to this cycle at the end of their useful life.  To stick to the 500 million garments, a sustainable collection a year does not save eleven months of fast fashion. It is a question of fundamental change, and that is what we are going to do with this action plan, and thank you for the good report and for the work that has been done.

name: Linea Søgaard-Lidell
text: renew group. Madam President! We're messing with our resources. We're messing with too much, and it's almost become a habit. This applies to us consumers who throw out our jeans or televisions instead of repairing it.  But this is also very much true of our shops and manufacturers, who throw out so many unused goods that you would think it was a lie. Just in Denmark, up to 700 tons of unsold clothing are burned every year. So these are goods where we have already used natural materials, water and energy to produce them, and that is a mess!  Instead, we must create a market in which resources are recurning. Where we don't just suck out finished products because the fashion season is changing. In fact, I see it as a huge opportunity for us: together we can create better standards for how we produce.  That is why I have proposed that we make it illegal to destroy unused goods. We must give our resources as long a lifetime as possible – then we also create a new market for recycling good materials.

name: Ville Niinistö (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the circular economy is our solution to save this planet, its ecosystems and also the wellbeing of our citizens. We have to remember to keep it at the core of both the digital and green reform of the European Union. I would like to focus on the industrial side in particular. Concerning the digital reform, we have to make sure that we also green the digital sector. 53% of digital emissions comes from services, data centres and infrastructure, while 47% comes from end-user appliances. This shows that we also need to start tackling data centres, making them more energy-efficient, while we increase the digitalisation of our societies. And we need to oblige them to run on renewables while using the excess heat from nearby industries.  This information also needs to reach consumers, and eco-design should be expanded to cover services. So, in essence, we have to make sure that the digital reformation of Europe is also green and circular.

name: Pernille Weiss
text: - Madam President! No one can have anything against a circular economy. We all have an interest in nurturing ourselves with the obvious potential it has for our climate, our environment, and yes, on the great blade also the future of the planet. But the way a circular economy is knitted together is not inconsequential. That is why I would actually like to warn you sharply about, excuse me, some naïve greenwashing that threatens to reduce the impact of the report.  For how does we envisage a total ban on companies destroying unsold goods if that is the only and most sustainable way to get rid of them? How do you imagine that it is okay to cancel what is basically private property?  I have noticed that so-called liberal colleagues are behind the proposal to ban and assault private property rights. Liberals who often refer to themselves as the voice of business, innovation and common sense in the European Union. Just not exactly in this case, which is why we must hope that the nonsocialist-liberal governments of the European Union will do so.

name: Mohammed Chahim (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the Circular Economy Action Plan has the potential to boost our economy, create new jobs and decrease our carbon footprint significantly. The question is, how can it become reality? We can create new products and create new ways to reduce, reuse, recycle and recover materials in our economy. For me, it is essential that we come up with the right legislation to stimulate companies to create business models – circular business models – and extend producers’ responsibility. Better designed products that can be reused – circularity by design – or simply made to last, or last longer. This means that we need to have clear targets when it comes to the use and reuse of materials – less on a voluntary basis, and more binding and clear objectives. At the same time, Commissioner, we have to identify the current barriers standing in our way, such as obstructing laws, regulations and fiscal rules or the lack of accessibility to financing circular economy ideas and products. The circular economy is how we can do more by wasting less.

name: Ivars Ijabs (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Mr Sinkevičius, dear colleagues, now, when we are struggling with the crisis and desperately trying to get back to growth, it is also time to rethink what we actually mean by growth. We can grow only if we learn to reduce the use of primary raw materials and introduce new recycling techniques, with a clear measurement of the ecological footprint of products and services, and this is what this report is all about. Electronic waste is a prominent test case here. Despite every effort to dematerialise the production, the amount of electronic waste is growing by 2% a year. This is not sustainable, and that’s why we call on the Commission to implement fully the circular electronics initiative mentioned in the report. First of all, it’s about the right to repair, not just physical parts, but even more importantly software. Second, it’s a guarantee of durability of products and the reuse and dismantling possibilities. And third, this is our common charger initiative for mobile devices, to make the life of Europeans easier and more sustainable. Thank you very much and my congratulations to Jan on this excellent report.

name: Hildegard Bentele (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Anyone who talks about the circular economy must talk about waste. Also about ordinary waste from our households, about plastics, biowaste, glass, paper, bulky waste, about market waste, about street sweeps, etc. Unfortunately, in many EU Member States, this waste or waste is still simply deposited, i.e. stored unsorted, and stored on ever-increasing levels – until Saint-Never's Day. Although separation, recycling and composting systems have been in place for a long time and, if it is not possible to recycle further, waste can be recycled thermally or mechanically or biologically.  We should have put a clear end to landfilling as the most polluting waste incineration. That would have been the right signal under the Green Deal. That would have triggered investment now, and we would really be closer to a cycle across the EU.  Unfortunately, neither the Commission nor we in Parliament had the strength to send out such a clear signal. That is why I stand by my appeal: keep your eyes and ears open and ask: when, Mr Mayor, when, Madam Mayor, will this landfill be closed for normal municipal waste and instead avoidance and recycling will be organised?

name: Christel Schaldemose
text: for the S&D Group. Madam President! For me, as a Social Democrat, it is vitally important that the green transition is both socially and economically sustainable. It must be possible to achieve a climate-neutral Europe that creates new jobs and, at the same time, protects our environment. The EU's new Circular Economy Action Plan is aimed at this.  It is possible, but it is not easy, because it requires fundamental changes in the way we produce, consume and recycle – not just in Europe, but throughout the world. But with the new action plan, we are leading the way in the European Union. We show the rest of the world that a sustainable society is possible: when we make demands on companies to make production sustainable, when we make it easier for consumers to choose the sustainable solutions, and when we cooperate even more on the reuse of our common resources across borders.  Together, we can create a Europe where we look after the planet's resources and ensure a healthy economy. It is a sustainable Europe!

name: Maria Spyraki (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Sinkevičius, the Circular Economy Action Plan(2) is a significant step forward. One of the main parts of the new plan is the binding EU target for 2030 and also the introduction of harmonised circularity indicators. Moreover, the Member States should include resilience in their national climate and energy plans by building waste strategies and policies and robust scientific data, improving the comparability of EU statistics. Our citizens should also be engaged to prefer affordable products that are respectful of the planet. The EU Ecolabel could be used as a benchmark for environmental sustainability. However, Commissioner, implementation is everything. That’s why it’s so important to facilitate Members States like my country, Greece, to create extended producer responsibility schemes with the eco-modulation of fees and tax incentives and other financial incentives promoting sustainable consumer choices.  The Circular Economy Action Plan is a huge opportunity for our market, for our people, for becoming pioneers on the planet. That’s why, Commissioner, we have to proceed with mandatory targets and due diligence of the products in order to set global standards and create a level playing field for our companies.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for this very useful and fruitful exchange. I have taken very good note of your interventions and comments. Thank you, in particular, for your strong political support to move our circular economy agenda forward. I’m reassured to see that we share the common objective of harnessing the circular economy potential to deliver on the European Green Deal together.  Let me very briefly pick up on just a couple of the issues you raised during this debate: plastics, textiles and the implementation of our ambitious agenda.  First, on plastics, within the new Circular Economy Action Plan, we will ensure the swift implementation of the 2018 EU plastics strategy, and it will take follow-up measures – measures to restrict the use of intentionally added micro-plastics in products and to tackle unintentional emissions, for example, from textiles and tyre abrasion, and from primary plastic production. It will also include requirements to ensure that all plastic packaging in the EU market is reusable or recyclable and in an economically viable manner by 2013, along with requirements on recycled content and waste-reduction measures, taking into account the activities of the Circular Plastics Alliance. Hence, a policy framework for biodegradable and bio-based plastics. Last, it will implement measures on single-use plastics. Now, on textiles, we are addressing the textile sector due to its strategic position in the EU economy and its large environmental impact. In the context of the COVID-19 crisis, this is also one of the sectors that would offer opportunities for recovery since it’s the key area in many countries that were severely hit by the pandemic. Textiles is the fourth-highest pressure category for resource-use of primary raw materials, which is taking place mainly outside EU. In addition, the majority of textiles currently end up in landfill or incineration. Only a very small percentage is recycled. So we are planning to develop a comprehensive strategy in cooperation with all relevant stakeholders in Europe and beyond.  More generally, on implementation, the transition towards a circular economy requires the committed involvement of the widest range of stakeholders. It’s crucial to improve the flow of information along the value chain and to bring together key actors that can share common challenges and barriers so that they can learn from each other.  The different services of the Commission and of national administrations have also taken up this approach. It’s not unusual that the circular economy agenda is led jointly at national level by the ministries for the environment and for the economy or industrial policy. Let me be very clear: we will be successful with the Circular Economy Action Plan only if we implement it hand in hand with the Member States and deliver our common agenda together. I very much look forward to continuing our close constructive cooperation now that we will roll out and work on the various legislative proposals in implementing our Circular Economy Action Plan. Batteries, on which the European Parliament will hopefully start work soon, is the first one, and several other proposals will follow over the course of the year.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 9 February 2021. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Sandro Gozi (Renew)
text: In writing. No circular economy without a sustainable single market. To this end, the Huitema report is moving in the right direction and confirms our commitment to success. There can be no circular economy without sustainable production and consumption. It is essential: to strengthen European strategic autonomy and to make Europe a world leader in the green transition; Make investments, including in research and development, in sustainable products and services; Have the right to repair; better inform consumers, including through harmonized labelling; encourage the adoption of green and innovative products by public markets; to put an end to practices resulting in programmed obsolescence; to ensure wider and better choice, as well as to ensure consumer protection for all European citizens. After all, there can be no circular economy without new rights for citizens. This is the deepest meaning of our commitment.

name: Rovana Plumb (S&D)
text: in writing. – I fully support this report because it is needed for a successful circular economy in the EU to: encourage cooperation between governments, industry, local authorities and civil society to achieve circularity in products and services at every stage of their lifecycle; support innovative approaches for an efficient and responsible use of resources; support models and practices that expand the useful life of products; promote regulatory action that ensure large-scale availability of economically competitive secondary raw materials, for the relevant waste streams, enabled by intra-EU waste shipments; ensure legislation for a circular economy; promote educational consumers campaigns; consider the environmental performance of manufacturing processes and products in green public procurement decisions; provide market surveillance and law enforcement authorities with sufficient capabilities to enforce product regulations and environmental standards. A successful transition to a fully circular economy will foster environmentally friendly practices, and boost growth and jobs through a novel business model, with no one left behind.

name: Grzegorz Tobiszowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The new Circular Economy Action Plan is an important climate and environmental policy project. However, it should be borne in mind that an insanely important aspect of this plan is the pursuit of increased efficiency of the European economy and the competitiveness of European companies. Greater sustainability of value chains will improve the competitiveness and profitability of European industry and improve the strategic autonomy of the EU economy. Especially in the context of the current crisis and supply chain disruptions, we have seen how crucial strategic autonomy plays. The Circular Economy Action Plan should be seen in the category of potential and opportunity. This is an opportunity for European small and medium-sized enterprises to grow and take advantage of new opportunities. But in order to make this opportunity a reality, the Action Plan must be implemented responsibly and effectively. Many small and medium-sized enterprises are already supporting the transition to more sustainable business models, but complex and unadapted procedures and administrative burdens are an obstacle. We must ensure that these obstacles disappear as soon as possible.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Juan Fernando López Aguilar and María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting its victims (2020/2029(INI)) (A9 0011/2021). I should like to remind Members that for all debates in this part-session there will be no catch-the-eye procedure and no blue cards will be accepted. Furthermore, as during the last part-session, remote interventions from Parliament’s liaison offices in the Member States are foreseen.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner Johansson, is there anyone in this European Parliament who doubts that human trafficking and trafficking in human beings is a criminal phenomenon of the greatest gravity? It is in its objective dimension, because of the stratospheric volume of business and profits it moves, but it is also in its subjective dimension, because it undermines the fundamental rights and human rights that European law most appreciates and which are enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  And that is exactly what explains why Directive 2011/36/EU represents a decisive step in this conversion of this European Parliament, when the Treaty of Lisbon and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union came into force, into a criminal legislator, a legislator for procedural guarantees and a legislator for the protection of fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter. Because that's what it's all about when we fight human trafficking and human trafficking in a crime that has transnational scope. And, therefore, the answer must also be articulated at the supranational European level, which is the legislative responsibility of this European Parliament. And we have worked, from the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, which I have the honour to chair, and the Commission on Equal Rights of Women and Gender Equality precisely in the ten-year review of this 2011 Directive of its normative content, to provide a more effective response against all forms of trafficking in human beings, which is part of the 2012 anti-trafficking strategy, but also in the European Union's strategy against organised crime and the European Security Union of 2020.  This is what Article 20 of the Directive in force mandates, a periodic review, and we have attended regular reporting discussions in 2016, 2018 and 2020. But ten years after its validity, the time has come to say that we are facing a crime that has multiplied by the accumulation of crises, from the Great Recession to the COVID-19 pandemic, and by the information revolution in the network, because this organized crime has multiplied online, not only to hide its benefits, but to exploit more cruelly and more cruelly its victims in forced begging, forced crime, forced marriages, illegal adoption, organ trafficking, reproductive exploitation and economic and financial exploitation of victims of trafficking.  That is why the report adopted by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs has an age approach, protecting minors, and a gender approach. Because age and sex are not only relevant but decisive in the pattern of exploitation and enslavement of people in the sex industry, in construction, in agriculture or in domestic service.  But the 2011 Directive notes a pernicious problem of impunity for traffickers and traffickers of human beings because of evidentiary difficulties and the difficulties of cross-border judicial cooperation which highlight the importance of training and specialized training of judges, prosecutors, crime prosecution agencies, law enforcement agencies and legal operators.  That is why the 2012/29/EU Victim Protection Directive emphasises the best protection this European Parliament must give when legislating against the sexual and labour exploitation of victims.  And here we must say that Article 18, currently in force, of the Directive on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings provides that Member States 'shall consider' the inclusion in their criminal codes, that is to say, they will consider the inclusion in their criminal codes of criminal criminality of the use, consumption or use of labour or sexual services of enslaved persons. But the criminal responses of the Member States differ and a more effective and more European response is needed, European criminal harmonisation, more effective. That is why we propose that Article 18 be revised: so that all Member States may explicitly criminalize the use, consumption or employment knowingly, consciously, of the labour or sexual services of trafficked persons, so that where it says 'shall consider the inclusion in the criminal codes' it says 'shall include in the criminal codes' the explicit penalty for the use, consumption or use of the sexual or labour services of trafficked persons. Because it is evidence that impunity is rooted in the small number of complaints and identification of victims, which is due. But it is also evidence that, at the moment, the landscape of sexual exploitation of women in the European Union is baited cruelly, it looms cruelly over women who have been victims of trafficking in human beings. That is why it is essential to take this step of amendment and we demand this from the Commission in the revision of the 2011 Directive: the criminalisation of the conscious use knowingly of sexual or labour services of trafficked women. In addition, our report is committed to a multidisciplinary approach, so that not only the reform of the Anti-Trafficking Directive is entrusted, but also its combination with the single residence permit, compensation due to victims and legal and social assistance with a gender and children's perspective.  Member States are also asked to include European funds and budgets, collaboration with civil society, a link to the asylum procedure to better protect victims of trafficking in asylum procedures and the establishment of legal routes. All with the aim of ... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, the crime of trafficking in human beings is a crime which infringes protected legal property such as life itself, health, physical and moral integrity, sexual and outpatient freedom, and human dignity itself. The practices that turn people into goods—violence, threats, coerces, extortion—are aimed at dehumanizing them into goods, and the suffering that is caused in them is immense, deep, enduring. That is why, with this report, we want to join forces and ask the Commission, all European agencies, all Member States and civil society to fight this horrific crime. Because, ten years after the Directive, this crime has only grown in our territory. Half of the victims of trafficking are European citizens. Unfortunately, ladies and gentlemen, these are also children. We have just received a report from the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime and it tells us that there is an alarming increase in the proportion of trafficked children, which has tripled in the world. A third of the victims are children, but in poor developing countries they are half.  Because, as has just been said in this rostrum, vulnerability is the characteristic of victims, poverty, discrimination, but gender discrimination, gender-based violence, is a substantial element. Therefore, the majority of trafficking victims are women: trafficking for either labour exploitation, organ trafficking or sexual exploitation — more than 60% of all forms of trafficking — where women are 92% of the victims. It's a gender crime: 70% of traffickers are men. Vulnerability.  And on the other side, impunity. It's just been said. We are only able to release 1% of the victims. As soon as we detain criminals, the heads of these criminal mafias, as the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime says, the world's second-largest criminal activity, against which we show great helplessness.  Therefore, in this report we call for a comprehensive holistic approach to the fight against this crime: not only the Europol and Eurojust agencies, but also the anti-money laundering agencies, because if we are to deal with criminals, these organised mafias, we are chasing money. The traceability of money laundering of their criminal polyactivity is critical.  But we cannot forget the other fundamental part of this crime, which are those who use the services of trafficked persons, and we have to criminalize and criminalize this use because demand encourages the commission of crime, increases its benefits. That is why, as has also been said right now, we call on all Member States to typify the conscious use of the services of trafficked persons. Finally, we have to work with the victims, Commissioner. The human rights-based approach of the victims of the Directive was the right approach, but victims need justice; they don't always have it. They need reintegration, they need repair and they need rehabilitation, and in order to protect them we have to identify them, and here we are failing clearly.  We fail to identify children, who are lost to us on migration routes; unaccompanied minors: EASO tells us that there are thousands of them, invisible. We fail in the early identification of victims, fundamental: that is why we have to work on the specialization of judicial and police agents. And, Commissioner, we must count on civil society, NGOs working to assist these victims.  We need to guarantee victims mechanisms of assistance and social services, safe accommodation, free legal representation, psychological support; we have, in short, to reiterate once again that the victims are only victims and that there cannot be a double victimization, there cannot be a double penalty: we only have to protect them.  Finally, consider the context of COVID—19, which increases vulnerability. And so, ladies and gentlemen, let's look around. Victims are in textile workshops; are in online advertisements, because, unlike other victims, I want to tell you that victims of sexual exploitation should not be hidden, they must be announced so that they can be sold; so, they're there, we just have to have the courage to look at them. And I end with a verse from our poet Pessoa, who said that sometimes the hardest thing is to see only what you see most. Let's all make that effort together and have the courage to look at them. They're there and you see them a lot.

name: Ylva Johansson
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, Susan is a young woman from Nigeria. A woman called Ivy promised her a job in Europe. Instead they gave Susan a short skirt and high heels. They told her ‘you’ll get used to it’. But Susan may never get used to it. Susan was afraid to escape, afraid to be sent back to Nigeria, afraid they would hurt her mother, but she did escape and she testified. In the end, the judge sentenced this woman Ivy and put her in prison. This is a story of exploitation. It’s a story of courage. But it’s not a story of justice. Men moved Susan to Europe. Men guarded Susan. Men threatened Susan. When Susan ran away, men beat her mother. Men used Susan’s body. And the men all got away.  I know that trafficking is as shocking to you as it is to me. That you too want justice for the victims. That you too are determined to end the trafficking of human beings. So I would like to thank Juan Fernando López Aguilar and María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos, and the European Parliament, for putting this report on the table. We must help the Susans of this world and step up the fight against trafficking in human beings. It’s obvious that we need to do more.  Trafficking in human beings is one of the worst forms of organised crime, carried out by cross-border gangs that exploit people, their labour and their bodies. Member States must fully implement the Anti-Trafficking Directive and the Commission will assess this very closely. We will help Member States by boosting the capacity of law enforcement and judicial bodies also across borders, perhaps with a knowledge hub to share best practices and information.  At the same time, the Anti-Trafficking Directive will have its 10th anniversary this year. We need to start looking if it needs updating. A full time anti-trafficking coordinator will be appointed. The traffickers treat human beings as tradable objects, as commodities. We must disrupt the economic logic behind this crime. We must cut demand by targeting users. 60% of trafficking is for sexual exploitation and 92% of these victims are women like Susan. Without users there would be no trafficking.  I will look at possibilities to criminalise the use of exploited services. We need to make it more difficult to exploit victims’ labour, and we should target high risk sectors like agriculture, care services and construction. Better awareness and communication campaigns in these sectors could help identify victims. We need to look at all the EU agencies that can help to tackle this problem. We must cut the supply of victims by breaking the criminal model of trafficking. To do that we must end the culture of impunity. Human traffickers now make nearly EUR 30 billion every year, worldwide. I want to target asset recovery more effectively.  To catch criminals and secure convictions we need to boost law enforcement cooperation. That is already a Commission priority – interoperability of data systems, updating the Prüm system. Our recent proposal to boost Europol’s mandate will help to fight all cross-border crime, including trafficking. We are working on a police cooperation code. To counter trafficking specifically we could increase data exchange on trafficking through Europol. We could improve coordination between Member States and agencies. We must harness technology against trafficking. Europol and the United Nation’s Office on Drugs and Crime are ringing the alarm bell. Traffickers are moving online.  We need to improve digital capacities of law enforcement for online investigations to detect recruitment and trafficking of victims online and illegal money flows. We also need to work closer internationally. Working with friends and partners to fight smuggling is essential to our new pact on Migration and Asylum. Breaking criminal networks will also be part of our upcoming action plan against migrant smuggling.  We should investigate if and how we can mobilise our foreign policy, security and trade instruments against trafficking. The traffickers aren’t selling objects, they are exploiting human beings. We must protect the victims by supporting training of border guards, police, social workers and others, to identify and save victims, efforts by Member States to help victims, with funding and sharing best practices, awareness raising on victims’ rights, and by building partnerships, for example with the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. Throughout, we need to keep three things in mind. First, this is a European problem. 70% of the perpetrators are EU citizens. Half of the victims are EU citizens. Three quarters of trafficked children are EU citizens. This is a European problem. Second, this is a gendered crime. Nearly three quarters of perpetrators are men. Nearly three quarters of all victims are women and girls. Third, that the most vulnerable suffer most. Children, mostly girls but many boys too, are forced to beg and steal, but mostly forced into sexual exploitation. In migrants and refugees, traffickers prey on children and teenagers on the road or in camps – especially unaccompanied minors who are perhaps the most vulnerable of all. I look forward to working closely together with you in the European Parliament to step up the fight against trafficking in human beings.  (Applause)

name: Loránt Vincze
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, as you said, Madam Commissioner, according to the European Commission, 75% of child victims of human trafficking and half of all victims are European citizens. The countries of origin show an uneven distribution, and central and eastern European countries – Romania, Hungary and Bulgaria – lead the statistics. These are grim figures but there are human beings behind them. Let us be clear, countries of origin and destination both have their part and responsibility in fighting these crimes. Trafficking has deep socio-economic roots and is related to the situation of vulnerable or marginalised groups – the Roma, especially. The proportion of Roma women and children among the victims was several times higher than that of the general population. Yet, there are still no specific measures to prevent trafficking through the national Roma integration strategies. Under-reported or under-investigated areas, such as labour exploitation, also call for special attention – in the agricultural sector, for example.  According to Europol, criminals coerce low-skilled victims from poorer countries into working long hours for a low wage in another country. They exploit victims and on many occasions they do not even pay them or let them travel back home. On behalf of the EPP/PPE Group, I strongly hope that such concerns will be taken up by the European Commission in a dedicated EU strategy towards the European Union eradication of trafficking in human beings without further delay. I would like to thank the rapporteurs for our common work.

name: Maria Noichl
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would really like to thank you for your speech, for your frank words. Europe is a promise. Europe is a promise to women in particular. A promise of peace. A promise of self-determination, of freedom of choice. Europe is a promise of non-violence. Europe is also a promise of fairness and responsibility. And I do not believe that there is a situation that is more contrary to Europe than trafficking in human beings. Because there it is exactly the opposite: it is not about fairness and non-violence. It is not about self-determination and peace. It is not a question of responsibility, but of one-sided satisfaction, of unilateral exploitation, of unilateral needs, and it is very, very often about violence. Once again, I would like to thank you once again for your clear words. We must combat trafficking in human beings in Europe wherever we suspect it, wherever we see it. And I would like, of course, to focus on trafficking in human beings for sexual exploitation from the FEMM Committee. Also in this house – and I am sure of that – there are men who are buyers, who are buyers. Statistically, there is a large group of men who are buyers who are buyers – and they are involved in the system of trafficking in human beings. And as important as it is to see the victims on the one hand, to protect them, to support them, to strengthen them, to get them out of the system, to allow them to leave, just as violently and forcefully we must therefore act on the perpetrator's side! We must clearly state that buyers are perpetrators of human trafficking and prostitution. This must be clearly stated! And I would really like to thank all my fellow Members here in this House for those who have this courage and who do not push the buyer's class somewhere, but are honest and open and say: she is also among us.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, dear Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am deeply shocked – shocked by the high number of women and children who fall victim to human traffickers every year: 60% of all victims are trafficked for sexual exploitation; 92% are women and girls, and 25% of all victims trafficked are children.  Colleagues, these aren’t just numbers. Behind every number there is a story of abuse of life, and of exploitation. We urgently need to address the root causes of human trafficking and break the profit model of traffickers. This report is a wake-up call to the Commission and the Member States because part of the solution is in our hands. We have this directive on anti-trafficking – so implement it. Investigate more and step up cross-border cooperation. Give tailor-made training to investigators, prosecutors and judges so that they can catch and punish the human traffickers. Give Europol and Frontex more resources to fight human trafficking and protect the children in migration.  Colleagues, every day criminals are making money from exploiting women and girls within our borders. This must end. Let us make the fight against human trafficking a priority – now.

name: Jean-Lin Lacapelle
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Madam President, I too rarely hear that trafficking in human beings is a scourge often - and also - related to the migration issue. Yet we all have in mind the images of slave markets in Libya, such as the testimonies of migrants abandoned in the middle of the desert or the sea by criminal smugglers. We have a duty to put an end to these trafficking networks which, on the pretext of misery, are developing thanks to the massive immigration policies that you put in place. And the migration pact that the European Commission is proposing will undoubtedly encourage these criminal networks and allow NGOs to be protected from prosecution when they sometimes organise hand-in-hand rescues with traffickers. Worse, by introducing the principle of compulsory reception on European soil of migrants recovered at sea, you are encouraging smugglers to abandon more and more migrants in the Mediterranean! So I urge you to correct this pact and stop being indirect accomplices of these traffickers. It is by taking back control of our borders and regulating our migration flows that we will combat parallel trafficking of human beings. Less immigration means less traffic. A majority of the peoples of Europe aspire to this common-sense policy, but the European Union, as usual, always aspires to the contrary.

name: Alice Kuhnke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we live in a reality where the perpetrators – the enablers – of trafficking in large part remain unpunished. We live in a reality where the victims – society’s most vulnerable – remain unprotected and often criminalised, and still the Member States fail to implement the Anti-trafficking Directive and thereby fail to combat effectively this brutal crime, increasingly organised online. The EU has still not managed to present a new strategy to combat trafficking, and anti—trafficking is now dealt with under the fight against organised crime. We, the Greens/EFA Group, find this approach inadequate. We need a new anti-trafficking strategy in place, with an exclusive focus on the fight against trafficking, making sure that the victims—based approach and the Directive are implemented.

name: Jessica Stegrud
text: On the other: The ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner Ylva Johansson, I would like to thank you for your support. Let me tell you about what is going on in the shadow of the so-called humane refugee policy that you are advocating. In 2015, the Nigerian mafia exploited the open borders to establish illegal migration routes into the EU. Now they are making billions from this business. Young girls, most without asylum reasons, are attracted with the promise of work in Europe. There are no promised jobs, but forced prostitution. Those who refuse are gang-raped and tortured. Some of those who have tried to escape have been murdered, dismembered and buried. Yes, you heard me right.  Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Strictly controlled borders, police cooperation and a rational migration policy had taken away the basis of this deeply inhumane and lucrative activity and given us the resources to help the more, the most vulnerable, on the ground. This is not humane. It's irresponsible.

name: Malin Björk
text: On the left group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for Now that we are looking at the eu's and countries' work against trafficking and trafficking in human beings, I have three things that I would like to send with you: I want to see more focus on those who are exploited, for justice, for support, on exit strategies for women in prostitution, residence permits and compensation for victims of crime.  This confusion with the closed borders and the fight against trafficking must be over. It is clear that the extreme right says that they want it, and that it would be good, but that is their agenda anyway. We will stop confusing migration with human trafficking. That's not how we fight it.  And – and this has been highlighted here in the past by colleagues – one of the most effective ways of combating trafficking in human beings is to target those who exploit. We must place responsibility where it belongs, namely with all those, at the whole level, who exploit. When it comes to prostitution, exploitation in prostitution, we must also punish those who buy. Those countries that do not dare to penalise sex buyers, who do not dare to go after those who are actually responsible for this exploitation, well, those countries should at least dare to criminalise those who exploit victims of trafficking. I guess that's the least you can ask for.  I would like to send this with the Commissioner.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam Commissioner, 72 % of victims of trafficking in the EU are women. Trafficking for the purpose of sexual exploitation is predominant, with the proportion of women reaching as much as 90 %. It is therefore not enough to fill the gaps and improve the implementation of the anti-trafficking directive in order to protect the rights of victims and combat criminal networks. The perverse mechanism for the supply and demand of human beings to be exploited must be combated, on the one hand through instruments to combat organised crime, corruption and money laundering, but also through measures to combat gender inequality and poverty. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the protection and care of vulnerable groups, such as women and children, which is, moreover, an even more pressing need today in responding to the challenges posed by the pandemic and the role played by the Internet and digital technologies in the proliferation of trafficking. Finally, they are decisive actions to be implemented, necessary, both in the context of migration and asylum, in which criminal organisations take advantage of the absence of legal and safe means to intensify their business, and to make criminal justice systems more efficient so that crimes do not go unpunished.

name: Frances Fitzgerald (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent contribution.  This debate is on trafficking, but let’s be clear what we’re talking about today: modern day slavery. Trafficking is nothing less than modern day slavery here in our Europe. Slavery that moves as much money as drugs, but instead moves young women into Europe, and from east to west in Europe.  It is for this reason that I cannot understand why it is not at the very top of the European political agenda. Modern day slavery in Europe requires intense and persistent action to combat it, comprehensive action within the criminal justice agencies backed by adequate resources, Member State cooperation – working hand-in-hand – and political commitment, permanent commitment, until it is eradicated. This is how we tackle modern slavery in Europe. But what specific actions can we take? Recognise prostitution as violence against women. As Minister for Justice in Ireland, I introduced legislation that criminalises the buyer and not the seller of sex. This model puts pressure on traffickers. Every Member State should do that.  Introduce an EU criminal assets agency and follow the money. That’s what we have to do, a stand-alone directive on sexual exploitation. When women are violated consistently, we call this rape. To adequately combat this unique and horrific crime a stand-alone directive is needed.  The criminal justice agencies must work closely together, tracking the gangs who carry out the trafficking. It’s long and painstaking work but it must be done and we must support victims. The horror stories are endless. We cannot stand for modern day slavery in our Europe. We need to combat it with full force.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you, Commissioner Johansson, for telling me about all the Susans in the world. It is ten years since the adoption of our Human Trafficking Directive, but every day of these ten years women and girls have been sexually abused. It didn't have to be that way. If men did not buy sex, there would be no market for sexually exploiting girls and women. A gender perspective is needed in all measures against trafficking in human beings. In my country, in Sweden, we have a sex purchase law, which we Social Democrats pushed through over 20 years ago. A sex purchase law that criminalizes the purchase of sex, but not the sale, and that is important. Trafficking in girls' and women's bodies should not be a trade in the EU's internal market. Girls and women should decide for themselves over their bodies and over their own lives.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Trafficking in human beings is one of the most horrible crimes. Depriving people of their basic dignity, sexual exploitation, depriving enslaved people of their lives in order to take their organs, or, finally, their use as a labour force must be ruthlessly and with all determination. The ECR Group has always supported all actions – including a European Union directive – that can help to combat this extremely heinous practice. As the vast majority of trafficking in human beings is cross-border, very close cooperation between member states' special services and police is necessary, with the support of Europol and Frontex as well.  However, the fight against this heinous practice must not be a gateway to the opening of the European Union's borders within what is described as safe and legal immigration routes. Such naïvy thinking, like the involvement of NGOs in supporting irregular migration, can cause much greater damage. This will result in even more victims falling into the paws of ruthless criminals in search of a better life. One point, Commissioner, men are also involved in the fight against this. Such a prostackie, one would say, recalling Strindberg's gender struggle does not serve anyone. As a former Interior Minister, I would therefore like to stress that very many men have been involved in the fight against trafficking in human beings, a problem only in the way in which this fight is conducted.

name: Eugenia Rodríguez Palop (The Left).
text: – Madam President, almost 75% of trafficking victims are women and girls treated for the purposes of sexual exploitation, although we are also talking about farm slavery, home servitude, forced marriage, begging and forced crime.  Many of these victims get caught up in hell because they don't have legal and safe immigration pathways. This hell is wanted to be condemned in perpetuity by the far right in this House, closing the borders of those fleeing slavery, even as minors, and criminalizing the work of NGOs. Its sky is the exclusive club of a wealthy few. The same right that sanctifies the family here is opposed to the right to family reunification of those who flee. They're called Christians, but they're not.  Finally, trafficking exists because there is a demand that makes it profitable. The desponable need to exploit the other's body, to force it for the use and enjoyment of one's own. My body is mine and so is yours. It condemns without mitigation pimps traders of human flesh, exploiters, slavers, consumers, accomplices and cover-ups. We want this directive to be fully implemented so that it is they and not their victims who burn in hell.

name: Pernille Weiss (PPE).
text: Madam President! If you claim you haven't seen them, that might be true. But it's also true that they exist: people trafficked by other people for prostitution and slave labor under the radar, far away from the authorities' spotlight, overlooked by most of us.  If you claim that they are all themselves aware of it, that they themselves wanted it, that they have always known what they were up against when they set out against the EU and along the way accepted indescribable exploitation, then you expect more from your neighbor than he or she as the human being who has long since given up his own dignity , can perform.  That is why it is essential that we in the European Union cooperate with those who are where the authorities do not strike. The invaluable and often voluntary efforts of civil society, which create trust and security and which bridge the gap between the otherwise entrenched situation of the trafficked people to a freer, healthier and more dignified life. Preferably at home in your own country again.  I have proposed the invaluable role of civil society in this text, which we will be voting on tomorrow. I look forward to seeing that you all vote in favour.

name: Margarita de la Pisa Carrión (ECR).
text: – Madam President, there are many factors affecting trafficking in human beings. We are in a society where the end justifies the means: in this way, it is easy to understand that people are treated as mere goods depriving them of their freedom and dignity in order to achieve selfish and often perverse goals. Unfortunately, many of these objectives have already achieved the competition for legislation; that said, in the service of anti-human rights interests. We cannot close our eyes to cruelties such as sexual and reproductive exploitation, slavery or organ trafficking, but we cannot be blind to illegal immigration. All these practices are inhumane and run by international organized crime networks that act with impunity, murky businesses that move a lot of money and also eager for power. We find it astonishing that he also manipulates itself with gender ideology to accuse the male of being violent by nature. Be honest, look at all the dimensions of the problem. To give them a solution, we'll unmask the culprits. I invite you to recover the transcendent value of the person in order to ensure that human rights are always and in any case fulfilled.

name: Εμμανουήλ Φράγκος (ECR).
text: Madam President, trafficking is part of the crime of illegal immigration. A crime committed daily by traffickers against the Greeks of the acritic islands, Athens, Thessaloniki, Evros and the rest of Greece. Those of us who deal with this issue are well aware that NGOs, their political patrons and trafficking rings are a chain of the same vicious circle that we will break. Entire Greek neighborhoods have been turned into ghettos, and why? To enrich some by filling our country with illegal immigrants. If we want to stop trafficking, we have to not make it easy. We have to guard our borders much better. We must send back the traffickers' boats to Libya and Turkey. And, finally, we must stop giving money to NGOs and also to Turkey that is involved in such circuits.

name: Ylva Johansson
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Members of Parliament, thank you. I can hear from you that many of you are very much engaged in this issue and there’s a lot of knowledge on this terrible crime in this debate. There have been many valuable and good proposals in the report and in this debate that I will of course take forward into the coming work of the Commission.  Trafficking is a modern form of slavery and I feel a strong support from the European Parliament to step up the fight against this horrible crime. We need to do more. Member States need to do more. We need to follow the money, to stop the culture of impunity, to support and protect victims, to strengthen police cooperation to tackle this terrible form of organised crime. Thank you for your engagement, thank you for the debate. We need to unite forces to be able to win this battle. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place Tuesday, 9 February 2021. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Trafficking in human beings is a form of modern slavery and a blatant crime often committed in the context of organised crime, violating fundamental human rights and the inalienable right of every person to dignity. Millions of people around the world are victims of traffickers every year: women and men, adults and children. Moreover, we have been seeing new trends for a long time regarding the nature of the use of victims, namely the use of victims for forced labour. Unfortunately, many victims and traffickers remain undeteced. However, statistics show that sexual exploitation remains the most common form of trafficking in human beings in the European Union, with almost three quarters of all victims being women and girls. Children make up almost a quarter of all victims of trafficking in human beings in the EU and the vast majority are girls. The effective fight against and prevention of trafficking in human beings must include, inter alia, actions such as raising awareness of trafficking in human beings, including in particular the use of forced labour, raising the standard of support provided to victims of trafficking in human beings, including minor victims, and, above all, improving the effectiveness of the activities of the institutions responsible for prosecuting trafficking in human beings by improving legal tools and structures and implementing best practices and strengthening international cooperation. Only a comprehensive approach to the problem of trafficking in human beings, based on the linking of actions taken and the strengthening of law enforcement cooperation, will allow for the effective fight against and prevention of trafficking in human beings.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the oral question to the Commission on European Skills Agenda for sustainable competitiveness, social fairness and resilience by Lucia Ďuriš Nicholsonová, Lina Gálvez Muñoz, Dragoș Pîslaru, Elena Lizzi, Kim Van Sparrentak, Anna Zalewska, Eugenia Rodríguez Palop, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000006/2021 – B9-0004/21). I should like to remind Members that there will be no catch—the—eye procedure and no blue cards will be accepted. Furthermore, remote interventions from Parliament’s liaison offices in the Member States are foreseen.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė
text: The author. – Dear President, Commissioner, colleagues, green course, digitisation has a huge impact on our lives, our work, our communication. The ongoing demographic changes, globalisation and the COVID-19 pandemic in particular are indeed changing and influencing the specificities of our work and forcing a re-and fundamental review of whether the skills and qualifications available correspond to the new reality. The Commission Communication "A European Skills Agenda for Sustainable Competitiveness, Social Integrity and Resilience" aims to provide a response to these challenges, in particular by ensuring that the fundamental transformation of skills becomes an axis of the agenda and that lifelong learning, which is enshrined in the European Pillar of Social Rights, becomes a reality throughout the European Union. In this context, the European Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs would therefore like to ask the Commission four questions. The first issue also concerns the setting of specific deadlines for the actions envisaged in the Commission Communication. In order to reflect the needs of the labour market and to contribute to a rapid and effective recovery from the COVID crisis, the actions set out in the skills agenda must be implemented within the shortest possible time. So could the Commission provide an overview with specific dates by which time the actions identified are expected to be implemented? Second question: the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the digital skills gap and further exacerbated existing inequalities in education, including gender inequalities. In addition, the number of people leaving training has increased, especially among the most disadvantaged groups in society. So how does the Commission intend to ensure that digital education is given special attention in both education and lifelong learning programmes? Could the Commission explain how it intends to ensure that education and lifelong learning programmes are of high quality and inclusive, so as to create equal opportunities for all, especially those belonging to the most vulnerable groups in society or living in rural or remote areas? How will the Commission support Member States to strengthen their efforts to ensure high-quality and inclusive education and lifelong learning programmes? The third point is that the implementation of the European Skills Agenda will require adequate funding. In order for this agenda to be successfully implemented, significant public and private investment at national level is essential in addition to the planned financing of the European Union. So could the Commission explain what concrete measures it will take to promote national public funding and private capital raising and to reduce the huge disparities between Member States in the field of lifelong learning? And can the Commission explain how it will encourage companies to contribute and fund training for workers and apprentices? And the final question is: could the Commission list what should be done to help Member States adapt their national education systems to labour market needs throughout the European Union? How to attract and develop people's talents and skills that are vital both for personal development of people, but also for increasing the competitiveness of European businesses?

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first I want to thank you, and in particular the Members of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, for this question on a very important topic.
