Indeed the Skills Agenda is the centrepiece of our efforts to bring to life the principles of the UN pillar of social rights and notably principle number one. This principle states that everyone, I quote, ‘has the right to quality and inclusive education, training and lifelong learning.’ We need to invest in people and in building a strong human capital to prepare and accompany the green and digital transitions, as well as to respond to the consequences of the COVID-19 crisis. Our goal is to empower people with education and training, with a view to boosting the creation of quality jobs and setting the conditions for a more innovative, competitive, inclusive and sustainable development model. You rightfully asked about the progress we made in implementing the European Skills Agenda. The agenda was adopted by the Commission on 1 July 2020. It is a five-year plan to help Europe develop more and better skills and to put them to good use. Since last July, 7 of the agenda’s 12 flagship actions have already been launched. Such actions include the Council recommendation on vocational education and training which we already had the pleasure of discussing in this House. We have also launched the new Europass platform. The remaining five actions will be launched in 2021, notably the initiatives on Individual Learning Accounts and on micro-credentials.  The agenda is centred around inclusive learning. It is vital to address this point across all actions, for example in the Council recommendation on vocational education and training. We also underlined the importance of digital skills, and digital education and training. This is even more fundamental in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic. Therefore the digital education plan for 2021-2027 adopted on 30 September 2020 puts forward inclusion as one of its guiding principles. We are also working on the Skills for Life initiatives to reach out to the most vulnerable and to create concrete opportunities for engaging with learning. Our ambitions will fail to reach that goal if we collectively do not invest. We need to make the best use of the unprecedented funding of the Union budget to tackle the economic and social consequences of this crisis. This includes of course the European Social Fund+ which can now be implemented following the agreement in trilogue between Parliament and Council’s negotiators very recently. Additionally, the Commission has encouraged Member States to use the Recovery and Resilience Facility where one of the seven flagship initiatives for reforms and investments is re-skill and upskill.  The European Parliament has played a central role in strengthening the position of education and skills in the legal framework of the Recovery and Resilience Facility. I thank you for that as there can be no recovery and no resilience if we do not ensure adequate investment in skills and in quality jobs, especially also in the transition from one job to another. Member States should put a strong emphasis on investment in skills in their national recovery and resilience plans, but we are working now with Member States to make sure that upskilling and re-skilling is a top focus area. This is not all. Skills are a shared responsibility and it is essential for everybody to play their part. This is why we will put in place a number of measures to unlock private investment in skills. We will look at how fiscal frameworks can do better to support reforms and investment in skills, and how enterprises could better report on their employees’ skills development.  All these efforts culminate in the Pact for Skills, which Commissioner Breton and I launched on 10 November 2020. The pact represents a shared engagement model for skills development. Partnerships should be created in order to respond to the skills challenges in different sectors and should involve social partners, too. To date, three skills partnerships are already in place and altogether EUR 11 billion have been committed by partners in industrial ecosystems to upskill their workforce in the coming years.  Yes, the question of helping Member States to align their national education systems with the labour market is an important one. Of course the organisation and content of education and training is a matter for the Member States, but targeted and up-to-date skills intelligence can help align training with evolving labour market needs, as well as support individuals in their choices. As part of the Skills Agenda the Commission, in cooperation with Eurostat and the EU Agency Cedefop, is improving and making more widely available such skills intelligence at regional and sectoral level. Let me give you just one example. A Big Data initiative using artificial intelligence has analysed over 150 million job vacancies across Europe. This is an example of assessing skills needs in real time. The results are already online and the Commission is disseminating our findings with key stakeholders such as the European network of public employment services and with social partners.  The Skills Agenda already in its name sets the path towards which we have to go: sustainable competitiveness, social fairness and resilience, and I know that I can count on this Parliament to go on this path.

name: Andrea Bocskor
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Resource scarcity, the transition to a resource-efficient, digitised and climate-neutral economy and the expanding use of AI are creating new challenges for the employment and labour market. New professions will be created, while the existing professions will be transformed or eliminated. This clearly indicates the need for rapid change in skills and skills in order to ensure the competitiveness of the European Union and its Member States.  The Covid19 pandemic accelerated the digital transition and showed the level of digital skills of different age groups. Because of the security measures, most of our activities have been transferred to the digital space, teleworking and distance learning have become part of everyday life for millions of people overnight, bringing to light the limitations of our digital preparedness. I am pleased that the new Skills Agenda for Europe also intends to contribute to addressing the economic and labour market challenges posed by the Covid epidemic. I welcome the forward-looking proposals and it is important that they lead a sustainable path for future generations. Modern, innovative and quality education and training, which are directly linked to the labour market and societal needs, must be very important in skills development, while also contributing to equip young people with important skills that will prepare them for real life. Vocational training and lifelong learning must be prioritised, as it is very important, through training and retraining, that they can always remain in the labour market, and it is very important to think not only of young people, but also of adults and the elderly.

name: Lina Gálvez Muñoz
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner Nicolas Schmit, all people and institutions agree on the importance of improving our qualifications and competencies so that our economies move forward in competitiveness, resilience and social justice, and to successfully move to a green and digital economy.  But are the competitions the ones we need? Who defines it? How and who accesses them? Are all people in the same position to access them?  Normally, as we approach the competition debate, we think that skills are neutral and accessible to everyone and w or not it depends solely on our merits and efforts. But is it really just an individual responsibility? I don't think we have to individualize the responsibility for these processes, or be neutral. For example, capabilities are not independent of gender or ethnic stereotypes, and therefore neither are the opportunities to obtain them throughout our lives. And individualizing responsibility for each person in relation to the skills they are able to acquire is unfair, because not all of us have the same opportunities, especially given the educational inequalities with which we come to the labour market and which have also increased with the pandemic.  That is why, from the public institutions and from the European Parliament, we must try to ensure that the qualification and requalification processes are accessible to all people, with particular attention to people from the most vulnerable groups, areas with higher levels of unemployment or rural and isolated areas. May these processes be free of stereotypes because we need all the talents for Europe to move forward in a more innovative and fair way. That learning processes be remunerated so that people from disadvantaged backgrounds do not play at a disadvantage. That these processes have sufficient budget and the active participation of all social actors and that they include digital capabilities to enable all citizens to have greater digital literacy... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Dragoș Pîslaru
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, here we are, finally having a debate that our group, Renew Europe, has actually been calling for ever since June 2020, when we launched a paper called ‘Skills at the heart of Europe’. Skills are actually the key ingredient for our future. It’s about our small entrepreneurs, it’s about research, it’s about how we produce the vaccines for the population, and it’s at the core of productive activity. Skills are actually about the social underpinnings of independent living, having good wages and being able to provide for your family. Skills are about the future of our society. There is no Green Deal or digital transformation without proper skill investment. Here we are with the ambitious new Skills Agenda for Europe before us. We are in the Parliament, putting the right questions and coming with our own contribution to this very important debate. There are three major things to remember. It’s about coordination, how we better coordinate so that skills are going to be sought in all the policy areas, and how we are going to have efficient implementation and transform the words in this nice motion for resolution into facts. That’s the question for the Commission. How do we use that funding for the future? This is the most important thing. So repeat after me: skills, skills, skills. This is actually the future for Europe. Thank you very much, and we are looking forward, as the Parliament, to supporting the Commission in the implementation of the strategy.

name: Julie Lechanteux
text: On behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, today's debate is on the European strategy for competences for sustainable competitiveness, social equity and resilience. A very convoluted title to talk about education, the training of our young people and the labour market that awaits them. Behind these amputated formulas lies a more raw reality that you do not assume, as usual: that of an economic crisis that is still in its infancy, with as a corollary endemic unemployment to which uncontrolled immigration is no stranger.  According to the latest Eurostat report on the European Union in November 2020, there are more than 3 million young people under the age of 25 who are unemployed, an increase of almost 17% in just one year. In parallel to this damning observation, the European Commission has only recently stated that immigration will be an inexhaustible source of talent. We're walking on our heads! When I see that the CEO of AstraZeneca is a Frenchman, I tell myself that geniuses, in France as in Europe, we are full of them. But for lack of political will and vision, and because of underinvestment in training and scientific research, you have scared them away.  So, Mr President, commit ways to train, encourage and keep our young people instead of forcing them to choose between unemployment or expatriation, and put an end to your pact on migration, which is a real danger to our jobs and our civilisation.

name: Eugenia Rodríguez Palop
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Mr President, the European Skills Agenda cannot facilitate only the transition to expanding sectors and jobs. It is not a question of responding to the needs of a changing labour market that fagocitates workers at convenience, precarious training itineraries and reinforces the instability of labour markets. We have to think seriously about the kind of professionals we want, not just the markets we have. The Agenda has to provide competence to those who need it most, thinking about them and eliminating the class, race and gender biases that perpetuate inequality, and not only to do justice, but because to be competitive you have to have all the talents and abilities possible.  We know that diversity is profitable; therefore, this proposal involves not only public authorities, but also companies: entrepreneurs have to improve the qualifications of their workers, avoiding favouring the usual, facilitating training opportunities and contributing to their training. It is clear that we must continue to strive for the good of all.

name: Daniela Rondinelli (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, investment in human capital is the key instrument for overcoming the current economic and employment crisis. The Commission's proposal, however, risks remaining a dead letter if we do not move towards an ambitious, concrete and monitorable European training model, based on the green and digital transition.  This approach must, in fact, include three essential conditions for quality training: the mutual recognition of acquired skills; the definition of decent working and wage conditions for apprentices, such as to prevent any form of exploitation, and above all the relaunch of local skills pacts, so that training evolves maintaining a strong link with the vocations and needs of the territories, thus accompanying the processes of productive transformation. It is only thanks to this balance between the European and local dimension that we will be able to restore dignity to training, which is an extraordinary source of employment opportunities and an indispensable incubator of social conscience and active citizenship.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – Mr President-in-Office.  The veryry that the coronavirus has already changed our labour market is now clear to everyone and this debate is really coming at the right time. In these days, decisions are also made on the number of enrolment places in education systems. I will mention only two sectors today.  Firstly, high on the scale of personnel needs are those involved in informatics, with computer science. These skills will be very important for our future.  We in the European Parliament, too, stress the importance of digitisation for our society, and if we are to achieve this, we must build on these technical professions.  The second area is the area of health. Many European health systems fell into an even bigger crisis during the pandemic, not because of equipment, but because of staff, which are severely lacking in at least some parts of the European Union.  However, pandemic is a short-term challenge, the greater the ageing population, when we need a lot of staff to take full care of our health. We have to think about all this today, not next year.  All calls for education systems to adapt to the market are traditional, but one step needs to be taken.  I hope that the Commission will do everything in its power to support such steps to ensure that the Skills Agenda for Europe is implemented that is more competitive.

name: Marc Angel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, according to Cedefop, almost half of all EU workers will need to update their skills and/or gain new ones to get or keep jobs and to embrace the opportunities of the digital and the green transitions, and therefore we Socialists and Democrats fully support the EU Commissioners’ efforts in implementing the Skills Agenda and the European Pillar of Social Rights by pushing Member States to join this path in order to leave no one behind. Member States must use money from EU funds – the Recovery Fund included – to adapt their education and training systems. Vulnerable groups must have an equal access to education, skilling and upskilling. The EU and Member States must avoid the creation of new gaps resulting from unequal access to technology, especially between generations, gender and between rural areas and cities. As Socialists and Democrats, we will stand with EU citizens and will support them to embrace transition without forgetting to strengthen, next to their skills, also their personal development and critical thinking. In a changing world, being aware of the necessity of the new skills agenda is crucial for both workers and employers.

name: Radka Maxová (Renew).
text: – Mr President, the coronavirus pandemic has absolutely changed our lives. Instead of meeting daily, we moved to the online scene, including employment and education. This has greatly exacerbated existing inequalities and made people's lives more difficult, and the European Skills Agenda can help in this. Within it, it is also important to think about people with disabilities and fellow citizens who, for various reasons, live on the fringes of society or directly in poverty. These people are not only threatened by the current coronavirus crisis, but also by the transition to a more digital world and an economy associated with the green transition. It is therefore very important to ensure programmes that develop precisely this education and skills, which will be linked to the change in the future labour market. The labour market will be strongly affected by digitalisation and the transition to green energy. We must also not forget in these programmes the promotion of internet access for all. This is the only way to use the current situation for a fairer society and equal access to all our citizens.

name: Stelios Kympouropoulos (PPE).
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues, the latest World Economic Forum Future of Jobs report shows that over the next years, 40% of workers will require reskilling of approximately six months. Having this in mind, the Commission’s Skills Agenda Communication has rightly placed skills at the heart of the EU policy agenda. We will need quality and inclusive training and lifelong learning opportunities for all, with a particular focus on the most vulnerable people of our society and workers in sectors that will undergo fundamental changes. Digital skills and literacy, green skills as well as competences such as critical thinking and problem—solving should be key elements in order to harness the potential of the digital and green transitions and bridge the existing skills gaps. However, this can only be achieved through a holistic approach, involving all relevant stakeholders and enabling us to anticipate the changing nature of jobs and the skills needed in order to adjust our education systems. And that is the only way to succeed in one of the biggest challenges of our lifetime: to enable our workforce to thrive in new job types that don’t yet exist.

name: Радан Кънев (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the health crisis has not only changed the labour market, it has, above all, accelerated the changes we have been talking about for a long time, but we have been talking about in the future. They're a reality now. Remote work, flexible but also precarious working hours, the displacement of traditional jobs from computer technology. And they come along with a severe economic crisis and increased unemployment. The problems became visible during the Kovid crisis, but they will not disappear with it. It is natural to hear today calls for increased state intervention, for a new role for governments, even the European institutions, for increased public spending. But if we try to force the labour market into the 20th century, we will fail, we will destroy our social market and our social systems. New public engagement, new public spending is needed, but they are needed not to stop the changes, but to support our adaptation to them. And they must follow only three priorities: education, education and education.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, long before the pandemic, we already knew that skills and learning were key.  With the COVID-19 crisis, the transformation of the world of work has accelerated exponentially, towards ever more digital uses. Our companies therefore need an even more skilled workforce to meet new challenges, especially preparing for the emergence of new trades. In fact, 65% of children entering primary school will be in a profession that does not yet exist. Today, 42% of Europeans lack basic computer skills. In addition, the current crisis is putting many young people in difficulty, with no internships, no mobility, distance courses, which will make it more difficult to integrate them into the world of work. More than ever, the links between training and the business world need to be strengthened. And with this in mind, learning must be valued as a path of excellence for professional integration and the acquisition of new skills. I therefore welcome this strategy which the European Commission wishes to implement, because it will enable us to respond to the challenges that the European Union is experiencing.

name: Antonius Manders (PPE).
text: Mr President, this crisis shows even more that knowledge is power. We have for years failed to adapt our education system, our education, our training to the market. We've always been into the old thinking. This crisis really shows mercilessly that we have done it wrong. I hope that it will be timely to introduce a permanent education for young and old at European level. Right now, we rely too much on big American tech companies. We depend on technical platforms from China. There are hardly any European companies that can compete with this, because we have been standing still for years – in our view– from the lead. It is time that we finally invested a great deal, free up time and facilitated that our workers in Europe can bring our economy back to the level that we were used to and that we will see that happen again in the future. Because we have the knowledge. Knowledge makes power and couples young and old.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would first like to thank honourable Members for this very encouraging debate. I would even say that there is a perfect consensus on this issue. We all agree that skills are the future. It’s the future for our societies and the future for our economy. Some have referred to the World Economic Forum and asked for a skills revolution, and indeed we probably need some kind of skills revolution because we have a technical revolution. We need a revolution in our way of producing, due to the need to adapt to climate change. Therefore, I think this skills revolution has first to guarantee to everybody, and remember I quoted Principle 1 of the Social Pillar, that everybody has to get equal access to skills, equal access to quality education, and equal access to lifelong learning, the young and adults. This is also something very important for Europe’s social model. It’s a basic element of our idea of equal opportunities. Yes, we have a revolution in the digital world and we have a lot of vacancies there which are not filled. Here it’s a challenge now to train people, to give them the right education and to give them the right skills. Sometimes we have to leave the usual models to skill them because technology also gives us the tools to skill people in a different way. We are talking about just transitions. I would say that this means first investing in people, investing in human capital, because our labour markets are changing. It’s true that they are changing and we should now anticipate technological change and prepare every person – every young person – for the changes and give them the opportunity to learn to learn. This is the challenge we all face and now we have the Skills Agenda and I agree that it’s up to us to implement it. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 10 February 2021. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Атидже Алиева-Вели (Renew)
text: in writing. – I am happy that the European Skills Agenda recognises the importance of lifelong learning and upskilling and qualification of employees in order to enable them to be well prepared for the competitive working environment. We must ensure equal access to training for all people, regardless of their gender, age group and ethnic background. People with disabilities should also be able to take advantage of the opportunities on offer. Changing working conditions and the transition to remote work imposed by the pandemic require all workers to increase their digital literacy and improve their digital skills. The Union is experiencing a shortage of qualified staff, and this problem will deepen in the future. There is no doubt that digital education must be promoted across the EU, especially in rural areas.  I am extremely pleased to see that the program also focuses on adults, providing them with more opportunities to expand qualifications and allowing them to be active in the labour market. The programme also covers young people, providing opportunities to enrich their work experience. The EU plays an essential role in supporting Member States' actions in the field of education and training, and each country must make full use of all the opportunities provided by this programme.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Özlem Demirel on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the reduction of inequalities, with particular attention to inequalities in employment poverty (2019/2188(INI)) (A9-0006/2021).

name: Özlem Demirel
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The EU, a place of prosperity, is always called. Yes, the EU is one of the richest regions in the world. Incredible wealth is piling up here. At the same time, however, one in five Europeans, 95 million people, is at risk of poverty. Old-age poverty, child poverty and poor work are the bitter reality for millions of people. Almost 6% of the EU population is affected by extreme material poverty. There was a promise to reduce the number of people affected by poverty by 20 million by 2020. This EU objective has been missed. Inequalities in the EU, both in and between Member States, have widened. The social consequences of the Corona pandemic are not yet fully understood. It is already clear that the gap between rich and poor will continue to diverge.  For this reason alone, there is an urgent need for action, not just tomorrow, but actually yesterday. We need europe-wide minimum standards, strong social security systems in the Member States. We need wages and pensions that guarantee a dignified life. While only a few years ago the Director-General of the International Labour Organisation said that 'work is the best way to combat poverty', this is far from the case for everyone. Imagine that one in ten people in the EU lives in a household affected by poverty, despite working. According to the official definition, you are at risk of relative poverty if you earn just 60% of the median wage. However, in hardly any Member State where there are statutory minimum wages are they above this poverty threshold. But those who work must not be at risk of poverty. Those who work must be able to live a dignified life. After all, it is the working people who create the riches in the first place. That is another reason why a clear and ambitious minimum wage initiative is needed. What do you get from having statutory minimum wages but not even protecting them from poverty?  Homelessness is rising, precarious employment is rising, temporary employment and involuntary part-time work are on the rise. With gig and platform work, spin-offs, bogus and solo self-employment, subcontractor chains, privatisations and liberalisations, wage undercutting competition has been fuelled – and all over Europe. This also weakens trade unions and erodes collective bargaining systems. The shrinking wage coverage, in turn, leads to a reduction in the overall wage level for all workers.  In 14 EU Member States, one in two workers works without a collective agreement. This usually means poor era, poorer working conditions and less job security. We have just seen it in crisis: temporary workers, mini-jobbers, temporary workers, workers with a work contract or a fee contract were the first to have to jump over the cliff. They have already lost their jobs.  But should it not be clear that there are social conditionalities in the European Union? Large companies, corporations are being bailed out with billions of euros in the crisis and are still laying off employees. That cannot be done! Employees are made redundant and at the same time dividends are distributed to shareholders. That cannot be done! It is clear that the crisis of one is the profit of others. While 75% of Europeans say they are in a worse economic situation than they were before the Corona crisis, the brand new Oxfam study shows that the richest ten people in the world have amassed €500 billion in wealth during the pandemic alone, increasing their wealth.  Ladies and gentlemen, with my report, you now have 73 recitals and 112 paragraphs to vote on this subject and other subjects. Other concrete measures have also been taken into account here. For example, we are calling for a European social security number, access to businesses for trade unions, special protection against discrimination and discrimination in the workplace, or the gradual abolition of zero-hours contracts. We call for initiatives for a minimum income, a child guarantee and an ambitious minimum wage initiative. Social concerns must no longer be subordinated to the fundamental freedoms of the market enshrined in the EU Treaties.  Commissioner Schmit, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has It is high time to act – for a life free from poverty and with dignity for all people, against precarious employment, good working conditions and social security in the Member States and in Europe.  I would like to thank you for the hard work we have worked with the shadow rapporteurs in the political groups and I look forward to working with you today.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, yes, it is more important than ever to speak about inequalities. So I would like ...  – Ihnen meinen Dank auszusprechen, liebe Berichterstatterin, für Ihren Bericht und auch dem EMPL-Ausschuss und allen Schattenberichterstattern. Even before the crisis while unemployment was declining, income inequality did not follow the same trends. In the EU, the income of the richest 20% was five times higher than that of the poorest. This afternoon, Ms Lagarde was here to address this Parliament and when she was at the IMF she put inequality as a major challenge for our societies. Recently she said, and I quote: ‘The bittersweet reality is that despite economic growth, there are still far too many people who are left out.’ Yes, the income share of the lower 40% earners has stagnated for many years, even in periods of economic growth. Equal access to opportunities remains a challenge, especially for children from disadvantaged backgrounds, and as President von der Leyen has put it in her political guidelines, we need equality for all and equality in all of its senses. The main social fallout of the COVID-19 crisis is still ahead of us. Unemployment can be expected to further increase and poverty and inequality are likely to follow the same path and therefore the crisis response needs to tackle inequality and poverty both in terms of policy and funding, and this has to happen now. In this regard, adequate, sustainable, fair and inclusive social protection systems play a crucial role. They help cushion the impact of a crisis and contribute decisively to the resilience of our societies. Reinforced support is needed to address youth unemployment, as the crisis has led to an increase in the rates of young people not in employment, education and training. The crisis has plunged a great number of young people into a really dramatic situation. They are experiencing real poverty and exclusion with a detrimental psychological impact – students who have lost their jobs to pay for their studies, the young who worked in the most impacted sectors like tourism or hospitality. Those with precarious jobs were the first to be unemployed. But there are also all the young performers in creative activities – the artists, the musicians, actors – they suffer enormously having no income and often no possibility to pursue their creative activity. We have to show solidarity with these young people if we do not want again a lost generation, or worse, a desperate generation. Gender gaps in employment and pay were stagnating before the crisis and are now at risk of widening. Yes, women’s over-representation in lower-paid sectors and occupations, the front-line workers, made them particularly vulnerable. Closed schools and reduced services did not help balance carrying the responsibility between men and women. As rightly pointed out in the report, in-work poverty strips work of the basic purpose of providing a decent life. In-work poverty was already high on our agenda before the outbreak of the COVID-19 crisis. We saw the last recovery did not reach all workers to the same extent. And we are committed to Principle 6 of the Pillar of Social Rights, I quote: ‘In-work poverty shall be prevented.’ And this means also that we have to combat precarious work forms. Providing jobs that pay an adequate wage is essential to guarantee adequate working and living conditions for workers and their families, reduce wage inequalities and build fair and resilient economies. Minimum wages play an important role in this context – adequate minimum wages. Still too many workers are not protected by adequate minimum wages in the EU. This also contributes to higher gender pay gaps. Our proposal for a directive on adequate minimum wages is now in the hands of the co-legislators and we hope for a speedy adoption. Inspired by the principles of the European Pillar of Social Rights, our proposal is ambitious and balanced and fully respects the specificities of national systems. We need adequate minimum wages and better coverage by collective agreements. These are the best ways to combat in-work poverty and poverty at large. The fight against inequality and poverty will be an essential part of the Action Plan to implement the European Pillar of Social Rights. In December, this House adopted a comprehensive resolution on a strong social Europe for Just Transitions. This is an important contribution to the action plan and a successful Porto Summit. The Commission has already presented important initiatives in this context: adequate minimum wages and collective bargaining; the SURE instrument; the Youth Employment Support package to prevent another lost generation; skills we just debated; guidelines on seasonal workers – they are not only very much exposed to the pandemic, but they suffer also from bad working and living conditions. The fight against poverty and inequality will take centre stage. The action plan will include proposals which the European Parliament has been calling for for years, such as the Child Guarantee. The Council conclusions of 9 September 2020 invited the Commission to make a proposal on minimum income, given the number of people without income due to the crisis and it is indeed time to review the Council recommendation from 1992. We need common criteria concerning the fight against inequality, because equality cannot be won by action at EU level alone. It requires Member States, regions, local authorities, social partners and civil society to actively work on the implementation of the Pillar principles including by looking more at the distributional impacts of policies. The next Multiannual Financial Framework and the Next Generation EU can support the right policies. In the MFF, the European Social Fund+ will be entirely dedicated to employment, education and social measures. The preparation of the national Recovery and Resilience Plans provides Member States with ample opportunities to support economic and social upward convergence. It is absolutely true that rising income inequality is the defining challenge of our time, as former President Obama put it some years ago. As this crisis has even amplified this challenge, it is urgent to act. Talking of competitiveness and growth does not make much sense, as Ms Lagarde said, for people whose work does not pay, as they do not actually enjoy that prosperity to which they finally contribute. Prosperity for all has been a major promise of Europe. Let’s be up to this promise.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Dear President, Commissioner, colleagues, I will speak on behalf of the FEMM Committee. I would like to draw attention to the fact that the consequences of economic and social inequalities were very worrying before COVID-19. Women still earn less than men. They bear a much higher unremunerated household burden. They are at a much higher risk of poverty in old age than men. However, the ongoing COVID pandemic has made the problem of inequality and poverty even more acute. Although the COVID-19 pandemic has indeed affected all sectors without exception, it is probably most affected by the service sector, which traditionally employs more women, and this pandemic will put even more women at risk of poverty, while at the same time their children will be affected by poverty. Therefore, here we have to find a joint effort, to make joint efforts to prevent this from happening. Women also make up the majority of health and social care workers, and it is therefore necessary to channel public investment into meeting the needs of women working in this area, increasing their wages and ensuring improvements in working conditions.

name: Cristina Maestre Martín De Almagro
text: drafts member of the Committee on Petitions. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the Committee on Petitions we have worked on this report by examining the situation of many European citizens who demand answers to the situations of poverty and precariousness they suffer in their jobs. Workers, mostly women and young people, who number around 20 million people in the European Union and who are the eternal victims of the legislative systems they consent to and even, in some cases, stimulate precariousness and underemployment. And we know that the effects of COVID-19 will increase these numbers of people who work but live in poverty.  It is therefore urgent to work with Member States and with trade unions and employers to drive relevant changes in the labour market to stem this impoverishment.  Indeed, Mr Schmit, we need a European minimum wage. We cannot accept that there are first- or second-rate citizens depending on the area in which they live, as there are some countries where the minimum wage is barely exceeded 300 euros. Therefore, we need a minimum wage that guarantees justice and dignity in employment.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: for the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, I thank you for this report as an important kick in the fight against poverty and labour poverty. But let's just say one thing at the beginning. Is labour poverty really one of the biggest in Europe? Is this the biggest problem we're experiencing? Let us look at what the poverty of workers looked like a century ago and what it looks like today. Of course, the European Union has a lot of tools to tackle in-work poverty, and it is certainly not quotas that we should be regulating.  Personally, I experienced 42 years of communism in our country. I have experienced a certain part of communism, and communism does not create an equal environment. Communism distorts the environment and makes a much larger gap between workers and those who do not work and who actively manage politics. I recall that growth is absolutely essential for the European People's Party in the fight against insecurity and poverty. Entrepreneurship, SMEs, innovation, the creation of a competitive and sustainable labour market need to be promoted. I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal on the Skills Agenda and firmly believe that we will combat poverty, particularly in this building, by edging and promoting innovation.

name: Marianne Vind
text: for the S&D Group. Mr President! It is scandalous that a full-time job is no longer enough to pay rent, secure food on the table and make sure that the electricity bill can be paid. But for more and more workers in Europe, this is the reality. Gritty employers earn the cash to send wages and conditions to the bottom. And the consequence is that millions of people become "working poor". We need to put an end to that. A concrete tool in the fight against social dumping and poverty is ID cards for posted workers. The card is intended to facilitate the control of social dumping by the authorities and to ensure that everyone knows their conditions of employment. The results for Denmark are good, and therefore such an ID card can be spread throughout the EU. But the ID card cannot be left alone in the fight against poverty and social dumping. That is why we must tackle the problems of bogus self-employment, zero-hours contracts and loose recruitment. That is why we must strengthen collective agreements and protect the right to organise. That is why we must introduce a social protocol and stop putting economic freedoms above the conditions of employees. We must also put a solid pressure on us to have an ambitious strategy for a healthy and safe and safe working environment for all.  There is plenty to address for Europe's workers. There are high expectations of us politicians and we should take the lead in resolving the problems.

name: Атидже Алиева-Вели
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, combating poverty and reducing inequalities at both country and Union level as a whole must be one of the main priorities in each politician's work programme. The existence of the "working poor" phenomenon is unacceptable, and the fact that such a fate is shared by more and more people in the Union is particularly worrying.  The current pandemic has further exacerbated social inequalities and unfortunately there is no one-size-fits-all solution. We need urgent measures and a holistic approach. A rapid recovery of the economy and the strengthening of the single market are fundamental. Small and medium-sized enterprises must have access to funding opportunities. It is important to ensure effective protection of employees' rights, safe working conditions, portability of social rights, and to provide sufficient opportunities for lifelong learning. We need more investment in our rural areas to improve connectivity and improve services. Colleagues, the fight against poverty can only be successful when the efforts of the European institutions, countries, businesses, social partners and civil society are brought together. Active work must be made at European, national, regional and local level.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, the European Union thinks it is acting on the real when it produces reports. However, nothing is more wrong, as is the case with this text on reducing inequality and the working poor. Indeed, the majority of this House pretends to forget that the European Union is painful structural reforms imposed on peoples, it is a quasi-religious vision of budgetary balance and austerity for all, it is the destruction of the labour code and the flexibility of employment, it is the abolition of social gains. The management of the 2008 crisis has put millions of Europeans into poverty because of the catastrophic remedies that the troika has put in place on our continent. Today, you pretend to have forgotten the social bloodbath by presenting the European Union as a social paradise for workers.  Worse, you imagine that it is the solution, when it is the problem. You use a crazy energy to write your dreams while your globalist policies are our nightmare. Social dumping, unfair competition, the destruction of our public services, savage globalization, mass immigration explain the precariousness and general impoverishment. I refuse to think outside these realities.  You're trying to heal the wound you've opened yourself. However, it has never been more urgent to operate on the patient before he gives his last breath. Stop this hypocrisy. Give the nations of Europe the freedom to act sovereignly for their peoples.

name: Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, in 2008, after the global economic and financial crisis, worker poverty increased in the European Union from 8% to 10%. The COVID-19 pandemic, a decade later, will have dramatic consequences. We are not talking here about the immense difficulties faced by the unemployed or the elderly with pensions that are far too small, but all those who have a job, but who do not support themselves. Atypical and flexible contracts, zero-hours contracts, false self-employment, temporary work, unselected part-time work... How can the European Union still accept these scandalous schemes which violently make the lives of all these poor workers vulnerable?  Poor workers: a contradictory and cynical expression. But as always, women are indeed the biggest victims of inequality in the world of work. As we know, feminized sectors are often low-paid and undervalued. And it is also the women who are most imposed on these contracts of despair. Single women with children, women who are discriminated against, women with disabilities, women with a low level of education... And with women's poverty comes necessarily child poverty, because it is women who buy the basic goods.

name: Elżbieta Rafalska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Poverty in the European Union remains a serious social problem and the fight against poverty is still valid. The targets set in Europe 2020 have not been achieved, and therefore also the target of reducing the number of people living below the poverty line by 25%. This is where the European Union's efforts must be met with the actions of the Member States.  Poland is such a good example of an effective fight against poverty. The reduction of inequalities, social exclusion coincided not only with the good situation on the labour market, wage growth, low unemployment, but also with numerous social investments such as the 500-plus family, maternal pensions, the valorisation of the lowest benefits, the school trip, also the increase in the minimum wage, which has increased by 50% in real terms over 8 years. This has reduced poverty by 1.2 million people. So you can!

name: José Gusmão
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur for her work and the shadow rapporteurs. The European Union has almost 10% of poor workers, but an even greater proportion of hypocritical speeches about the situation reached by these workers.  The same political center and European institutions that deplore the situation of poor workers have actively promoted the precarious working relationships that have generated and aggravated this situation.  The European Union regulates almost everything that is available to regulate the goods and services circulating in its internal market, but not only does not regulate but also promotes the deregulation of the rights of workers who produce and provide these goods.  The European Union enforces and imposes deficit targets, but despises, ignores and fails its own targets in combating poverty. A good example of this laxity is the Minimum Wage Directive, which is in fact not a directive at all, because it does not even require the existence of a minimum wage in all Member States. This is where we have to start taking labour rights seriously if we want to take the problem of poverty at work seriously.

name: Daniela Rondinelli (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Europe over the last decade, the number of poor workers has increased by 12 %, and in my country, Italy, by 28 % The lack of work obliges millions of people to accept any contract or salary because what little they have is the only alternative to combating poverty and social exclusion. Unreserved digitalisation puts at risk the fundamental labour rights that have been won over the last century. This resolution identifies the scope for action urgently needed, from the minimum wage to the right to disconnect from platform workers.  We in the Five Star Movement support this proposal, but we will not accept downward compromises, and we reiterate the need to amend the European Semester upstream, putting environmental and social development on an equal footing with macroeconomic governance. Only in this way will the European Conference in Porto in May be able to fully reaffirm the dignity of work, hence the new European social model that we will leave to future generations.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE).
text: Mr President, we have not achieved the target we had set ourselves to reduce the number of people at risk of poverty by 20 million by 2020. Quite the contrary. Although the ILO President said a few years ago that working was the best remedy for combating poverty, today is no longer the case for everyone. The number of working poor is rising and will continue to rise due to the corona crisis and the growth in the number of precarious jobs where workers have hardly adequate protection – just think of the platform workers.  Unlike the previous crisis, we can use this health crisis to focus on quality jobs with dignified working conditions. Our employees earn a fair income and are entitled to a working environment where the protection of their health and safety is guaranteed. For this, we need a strong commitment from the social partners. The announced action plan for the full implementation of the social pillar will therefore come nothing too soon to combat rising poverty and inequality in the workplace. Principle 6 is crystal clear about this. We are eagerly awaiting the European framework for minimum wages, Commissioner. Because as Commission President Von der Leyen has said, a minimum wage works and it is time for work to pay.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: Mr President, people are waiting for us day in and day out, so that society can go crazy. The maternity nurses, the supermarket fillers, the forklift drivers in the distribution centres: they do not have the choice to work from home. They are at risk for us, but their hard work is hardly appreciated. The fact that there is poverty among people who work hard in the Netherlands, in Europe, is actually inescapable. Inequality is growing within and between countries. We have to, and we can turn that around. It is our plan to make minimum wages fair wages, to give people security about their income and their work schedule by abolishing zero-hours contracts, and to give platform workers such as meal delivery workers equal rights. At the social summit in Porto, we can make binding agreements on this.

name: Sylvie Brunet (Renew).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, tackling the growing phenomenon of worker poverty is an absolute necessity for all of us. Indeed, the share of European workers at risk of poverty was 9.4% in 2018, more than one point compared to ten years ago. This is an unacceptable reality that is likely to be further exacerbated by COVID-19. I am strongly in favour of the introduction of a minimum wage in every country in the European Union. A real social shield must be put in place quickly so that every worker can benefit from it, which would ensure a decent standard of living. At the same time, it is imperative that social cohesion and convergence be strengthened upwards. I would also like to stress the situation of economic fragility of women or some atypical workers whose functions are nevertheless essential to the maintenance or relaunch of the activity. Finally, it is clear that such measures must be part of a comprehensive framework to combat poverty. This is absolutely essential to reduce inequalities in our societies.

name: Guido Reil (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Work. Work is the best way to combat poverty. Unfortunately, this principle no longer applies in the European Union.  And now today we are discussing a report by Mrs Demirel on working poverty, which says a lot of the right thing. But what surprises me is that the situation in Germany is not mentioned in a single word in this report, because we are once again at the forefront here in Germany. Rich Germany: we are not only the paymaster of the European Union, we are once again at the top. Not only do we have the highest non-wage labour costs and energy prices, no, we also have the largest low-wage sector in the whole of the European Union. Eight million people work in Germany in the low-wage sector. In other words, they earn less than EUR 10.80 – 8 million people.  How did this happen? The Pandora's box has been opened by social democrats. Social Democrats have once again betrayed the working class with the 2010 Agenda. And what happens next? What does .B. Mrs Demirel do with the left? The policy of open borders – the policy of open borders leads to wage dumping and modern slavery, to nothing else, that leads to poverty.  Then there is the policy of the Greens, who, for ideological reasons, want to put an end to our industry once and for all, who are constantly pushing ahead with industrialisation and thus destroying the last well-paid jobs in Germany. This policy - this policy leads to poverty. And we must prevent that. The European Union is the problem. It is not the solution.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Mr President, the debate on measures against inequalities is in fact aimed at adapting labour rights to the demands of monopolies in the so-called green digital economy at a time when the new capitalist crisis, the measures taken by urban governments — and they are trying to make them permanent — on the pretext of a pandemic have put workers in a very dire position. In Greece, the policy of the European Union and the New Democracy government has reduced labour incomes by a further 12 %, while a new attack is being prepared for ten hours of work, the abolition of overtime calculation, the criminalisation of trade union action and strike action, i.e. based on the appetites of employers and in fear of unemployment. The report guarantees the European Pillar of Social Rights — an anti-labour mechanism that squeezes popular rights to a minimum by consolidating the commercialisation of health, insurance and education. The scraping of labour rights is therefore a necessary precondition for the implementation of the strategy that will bring entrepreneurs 'hot' money. Workers have a choice: to fight organized for their modern needs and rights so that they do not again pay for the capitalist crisis, against exploitation and the system that gives birth to it.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Hungary chose the job over the benefits. When there's work, there's everything. Most of all, it's a chance to reduce poverty. In hungary, the government has reduced poverty by tangible means: tax cuts, support for families and children, responsible fiscal policy. According to OECD data, the gap between the poorest and the richest has steadily decreased between 2010 and 2018 and is currently even lower than the OECD national average. Smaller than germany, for example. The report contains a set of laid-back promises. Tax increases are the only way to cover them. The Hungarian left is openly in favour of raising taxes with the introduction of the property tax, the property tax. His plans also include an increase in personal income tax and a change and increase in corporation tax.  Let's see what we can do. Minimum incomes and above the minimum pension are already intended to be created. They want to give NGOs direct access to EU funds. A reference to social dumping would hinder eastern European citizens. We tried to improve the text together with the Fides and the People's Party. We hope that it will really serve that purpose. We must always reduce the gap between the richest and the poorest.

name: Estrella Durá Ferrandis (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we must decide which model of society we want: the one which favours efficiency and competitiveness over social justice or the one that puts people first? What has moved us towards the welfare state is not the exploitation of workers or the privatization of public services. Our European Union is the superlative example of a social market economy, where competitiveness is achieved while improving the living conditions of citizens. And this is done with models that bet on public intervention and investment, protection of labour rights, decent wages, collective bargaining, progressive fiscal policy and combating tax fraud. The European Union is the crucible of fundamental rights. There will be those who will say, Yes, but they are also economic competitiveness. I say to you, "Is it possible to live a life without dignity, without social justice?" Let us therefore choose the right model because, if not, when inequalities and poverty continue to grow, it will be politics that will have become inefficient.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: Member of the Commission. Herr President, ladies and gentlemen, the COVID-19 crisis, the pandemic, is probably a natural disaster. Poverty, the fact that children are condemned to exclusion, is not a natural disaster. This is the result of profound dysfunctions in our society. If this is the result of deep dysfunctions in our society, we have the key - to make amends and change that. I agree: we need economic growth, sustainable growth, respect for nature, respectful of ecological balances. Respectful, too, of the work of women and men. We need innovation, and that is why we have been discussing investment in human capital, in education. We need entrepreneurs who create wealth, who create businesses. But what we also need, and I come back to Mrs Lagarde's formula, is that everyone gets their share, that everyone feels that their work is honoured, that they are working with dignity. In the end, that is what we must pursue, because what is at stake is the cohesion of our societies, and the future of our young people, of our children. But it is also the future of Europe. Because we hear, even here, sirens telling us that all this, of course, is Europe's fault.  That is why the Porto summit, the implementation of an ambitious social action plan, is so important. Yes, an adequate minimum wage is crucial. This is crucial for all those who work and cannot live off their work with dignity. I appeal to the conscience of all those who have doubts, who have legal or other reservations about this course for minimum wages. Think for a moment about the millions of workers who sometimes work more than 40 hours a week and cannot provide their families with a dignified life. I believe that making progress with an adequate, appropriate minimum wage, which improves their living conditions, which also improves their working conditions, is the least europe can offer them.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 9 February 2021. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Stefania Zambelli (ID)
text: in writing. – The Covid-19 pandemic has exacerbated social and economic inequalities, with the risk of worsening in the near future. Policies must be put in place to mitigate these effects, but the answer cannot and must not be new legislation at European level on pensions, wages and minimum income. I would like to point out, in fact, that these are and remain exclusive competences of the Member States. It is up to them to decide whether or not to introduce a national minimum wage by means of a joint discussion with all the social partners concerned. Furthermore, I think it is unthinkable to be able to recover from the crisis with over-regulation and subsidies: they are not a solution, but a new burden on companies and workers. It is necessary to put people in a position to work and create jobs, since decent employment is the only useful tool for not falling into poverty. Finally, it must be stressed that illegal immigration is having an extremely negative impact on the world of work, with effects on the level of wages and the precarious nature of many jobs.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the impact of COVID-19 on young people and sport by Sabine Verheyen on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education (O-000074/2020 – B9-0005/21) (2020/2864(RSP)).

name: Sabine Verheyen
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The crisis caused by the Covid-19 pandemic affects many aspects of our lives. But the young generation and the sports sector in particular are among the most affected. The ongoing pandemic is hitting young people disproportionately. Young people in particular will feel the serious negative consequences of the crisis in the future, as they face the challenge of successfully continuing their education, managing the transition to the labour market and maintaining their social and economic life despite the lockdown. In sport, the months-long cancellation of all events and the reopening of the stadiums in camera has led to enormous financial tensions among the associations and the sports organisers. And even more dramatically, grassroots sport has been almost completely brought to a standstill for almost a year. An irrevocable loss for smaller clubs and the social, social and health function of sport. In view of the devastating impact of the pandemic on the youth sector, sport and sectors and industries dependent on it, this motion for a resolution is an important signal and must be adopted by Parliament as soon as possible and the measures taken by the Commission. As far as young people are concerned, this motion for a resolution assesses the many damage that the current pandemic is causing to Europe's young people in terms of access to education, youth activities and the participation of young people in social and economic life. The resolution proposes a number of measures to address the catastrophic impact of the pandemic on the youth and sports sectors. In particular, it calls for greater financial support for the most vulnerable and greater flexibility in promoting informal education systems across the EU. We need special attention to all forms of education, vocational training, formal and informal education. We call on the Commission and the Member States to mobilise all available EU programmes and funding to cope with the digital transformation and modernisation of informal education systems, as well as to accompany young people in their social and professional integration in these difficult times. As one of our priorities, we emphasise the crucial importance of formal and non-formal learning, arts and culture, sport, voluntary work and social activities for the promotion of youth participation and social cohesion as instruments that have a huge impact on local communities and can contribute to addressing many societal challenges. Youth organisations play a crucial role here. Especially under Corona conditions, they need special support to maintain their operation under the restrictions. We should place a greater focus on young people in the recovery plans in order to contribute to the European digital strategy and to the realisation of a digital single market, but above all to make young people more involved in these processes. We are therefore pushing to increase investment in digital structures and skills development to acquire practical skills, skills and qualifications, and to improve the overall level of digital skills and competences in the context of the implementation of the Digital Education Action Plan. Not only in the formal, but above all in the informal field of education. The second part of the resolution deals with the devastating consequences that the pandemic still has for both professional and, above all, grassroots sport. We must focus on reducing the damage to the sports sector, not only in terms of the economy and employment, but also in society as a whole. We must be aware of the many benefits of sport for society in terms of public health, social inclusion, integration and cohesion. And in order to avoid lasting damage to the sector, substantial support is needed. The Commission and the Member States must make use of the available EU programmes and also ensure full access for sport to the Building and Resilience Facility, the European Regional Development Fund and cohesion policy funds, as well as the European Social Fund Plus and EU4Health. We also need a thorough assessment of the economic and social impact of the Covid 19 pandemic on sport and youth and a European approach to addressing medium- and long-term challenges. This must include a structured and systematic exchange of best practices between Member States, as well as enhanced dialogue and cooperation with stakeholders. We call on the Commission to coordinate all measures to deal with the consequences of the Covid 19 pandemic for sport in a separate EU action plan. The general reconstruction instruments adopted by the EU in response to the crisis must help to support the sports sector in the short term and to do more for our young generation.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the rapporteur and chair of the CULT Committee, Sabine Verheyen, and to all of you for this important resolution which sends a very strong signal, a signal of support for our youth and for sport.  First of all, with regard to youth, let us start from the observation that young people are the most affected by the crisis we are experiencing. However, even when hard hit by this crisis, young people have also been able to show great resilience and have presented solidarity initiatives of impressive magnitude. In the face of this, what can be done? What can be done to avoid a lockdown generation? Over the past few months, we have adjusted our Erasmus instruments and the European Solidarity Corps to respond to these disruptions, by offering alternative solutions, particularly digital, to their activities.  First, ongoing dialogue with youth and our national agencies. At the end of April, we launched an investigation into how the epidemic has affected the normal course of Erasmus mobility activities or the European Solidarity Corps. The results of the survey indicate that in higher education, the vast majority of students have managed to continue their mobility. Of course, the majority continued their mobility with virtual and online learning activities, whether in their home country or in their home countries. 75% of participants returned home, while about 25% stayed abroad.  To continue this work, we intend to present a European report on youth in the third quarter of this year, paying particular attention to the impact of the pandemic. It will inform the preparation of future political priorities as part of the Youth Union's 2022-2024 work plan.  Second, on the employment front, in July, we strengthened our support for youth employment with the YES (Youth Employment Support) initiative. In October, the Council adopted our proposal for a stronger and more inclusive youth guarantee, with an age limit increased from 25 to 30.  Thirdly, on the education front, through the Digital Education Action Plan, we have focused on the need to develop digital skills as well. And also, Mrs Verheyen, let it not only be formal training, but also informal. That is why I am citing as an example the digital opportunities internship initiative which, during this year, will be expanded and expanded to include internships for learners and apprentices in the training and vocational education sector.  Finally, we must also use the opportunities offered by the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, which plans to train more than 12,000 girls with digital and entrepreneurial skills by the end of the year in order to increase their employability, particularly in digital sectors.  Of course, there is also mixed mobility. This mixed mobility, it will be and will be part of the solution, but let it be very clear: the idea is not to replace physical mobility, which will remain a unique and irreplaceable experience. But participants can start with virtual mobility and then pursue it with physical mobility.  Now, with regard to the new Erasmus programmes and the European Solidarity Corps, thanks also to your efforts and the substantial budget envelope, there will be more opportunities for our young people. We need to include them more in initiatives such as the Future of Europe Conference or the new Bauhaus initiative.  I would also like to make an update on sport: the COVID-19 crisis has once again highlighted how essential sport is as a source of economic activity and employment, but also for our physical and mental well-being. While large clubs probably have some room to absorb temporary revenue losses, the very existence of many amateur leagues or less popular sports is threatened. This puts our European model of sport at risk.  From the outset, we have pledged to support states with an unprecedented set of economic measures to support both mass sport and the sport economy, notably through the three horizontal initiatives that are the Coronavirus Investment Initiative, the SURE instrument, but also the flexibility granted in the application of state aid rules. And, of course, the flexibility of the Erasmus sports chapter. Thanks to your efforts, the 'sport' chapter of the Erasmus programme, which remains our source of sport-specific support, will benefit from an increase in Significant. Let us also remember that regional funds have a role to play. As such, let me mention the SHARE initiative, which raises awareness of funding opportunities to support sport and physical activity in the context of local and regional development.  In this context, the joint action plan with the Committee of the Regions makes perfect sense, as it aims to maximize the impact of our policies on the territory. And to get a clearer picture, we carried out a study on the economic impact of the COVID-19 crisis on the sports sector. The results were published in November and its conclusions leave no doubt that the sports sector has been severely affected by this crisis.  However, as I said at the beginning, sport has once again demonstrated that it is essential to our lives. And despite all the difficulties, our sixth edition of European Sport Week has reached more than 15 million European citizens through more than 32,000 events. As part of the European Union's 2021-2024 work plan, adopted in December, we intend to create a group of experts to support the recovery and resilience of the sector. Next week, I will also be organizing the first meeting of the high-level group on gender equality in sport. Finally, I am committed to following up on Tartu's call for a healthy lifestyle launched in 2017. This new initiative, healthy lifestyle For All, will have cross-sector cooperation at its heart. Today, more than ever, we must also link sport with health, the environment, innovation, youth and skills. And that is also what is at the heart of our actions. I look forward to continuing the dialogue with you on this subject.
